entry.title: Cryptocurrency
entry.content:
Basic introduction of cryptocurrency

1 What is cryptocurrency?

Cryptocurrency is a form of payment that can be exchanged online for goods and services. Many companies have issued their own currencies, often called tokens, and these can be traded specifically for the good or service that the company provides. Think of them as you would arcade tokens or casino chips. Youâ€™ll need to exchange real currency for the cryptocurrency to access the good or service.

Cryptocurrencies work using a technology called blockchain. Blockchain is a decentralized technology spread across many computers that manages and records transactions. Part of the appeal of this technology is its security.

2 Why popular?

Cryptocurrencies appeal to their supporters for a variety of reasons. Here are some of the most popular:

  • Supporters see cryptocurrencies such as Bitcoin as the currency of the future and are racing to buy them now, presumably before they become more valuableï¼ˆå‡å€¼ï¼‰
  • Some supporters like the fact that cryptocurrency removes central banks from managing the money supply, since over time these banks tend to reduce the value of money via inflationï¼ˆç§å¯†ï¼‰
  • Other supporters like the technology behind cryptocurrencies, the blockchain, because itâ€™s a decentralized processing and recording system and can be more secure than traditional payment systemsï¼ˆæŠ€æœ¯æ§ï¼‰

3 How it worksï¼Ÿ

3.1 Decentralize:

In traditional electronic tradingï¼Œ there will always be a trusted third party either country\Bank or big company like Alibaba. In cryptocurrency there is no such "Center".

3.2 Block Chain:

Since, there is no centralized third party we need another way to verify and record transaction. The main idea behind cryptocurrency is to let everyone keep the whole e-ledger--the block chain.

In every 5 minutes someone will pack all the transactions(block) then he will broadcast to everyone and link the new block to the block chain.Every block will be encrypted by hash function.For bitcoin, it uses POW algorithm wich is based on SHA256.

SHA256(Plain Text) = 010101101010..0101(256 bit)

In short:

Ledger-Trust+Cryptography=Cryptocurrency

3.3 Why this works?

  1. It satisfy the basic requirements to be used as "currency".

    currency = transaction history

  2. Althoug there is no provement of non-solvable property of SHA256 but we can assume it is not possible to solve it. So it is hard(expensive, 51% attack) to forgery.

    Fraud is computationally infeasible

4 What is mining?

4.1 Block reward

Block Award:

Once a new block is added to the block chain, the people who finish such job will get rewarded for 25 bit coins**(halve after every 210000 blocks,and for now each block is rewarded for 12.5 btc)**

4.2 Who can get reward?

To get the reward one must get the opportunity to add a new block. This is where cryptography works.

SHA256 algorithms will translate plaintext into 256 binary code, the cryptocurrency protocol will announce, for example: first 30 bits should be 0 for next block. Miners will try different keys until one lucky miner find the key that satisfies the requirement.

SHA256(ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚+transaction+Time Stamp+ã€‚ã€‚ã€‚+key) = 0000...0001010111

4.3 Proof of work

The miners may get conflict signals recording conflict transactions. Miners should always trsust one with more computational work.

Some times conflict may come from the broadcast speed.For example one may get 2 blocks at the same time, then he sholud keep both blocks and one of them will gradually get longer and longer than another one, then based on proof of work protocol he should take the longer one.

Some time fraud may come from fraud. It is obvious that to make others trust your record you have to make sure your chain grows faster than the true chain, which means you have to posses at least 51% computation power which is not possible.

5 Problems

5.1 Speculation and fraud

Cryptocurrencies have been compared to Ponzi schemes, pyramid schemes and economic bubbles, such as housing market bubbles. Howard Marks of Oaktree Capital Management stated in 2017 that digital currencies were "nothing but an unfounded fad (or perhaps even a pyramid scheme), based on a willingness to ascribe value to something that has little or none beyond what people will pay for it", and compared them to the tulip mania (1637), South Sea Bubble (1720), and dot-com bubble (1999). The New Yorker has explained the debate based on interviews with blockchain founders in an article about the â€œargument over whether Bitcoin, Ethereum, and the blockchain are transforming the worldâ€.

(æ³¡æ²«ä¸åºæ°éª—å±€)

5.2 legal concern

Cryptocurrency networks display a lack of regulation that has been criticized as enabling criminals who seek to evade taxes and launder money. Money laundering issues are also present in regular bank transfers, however with bank-to-bank wire transfers for instance, the account holder must at least provide a proven identity.

ï¼ˆæ´—é’±ï¼Œéæ³•æ±‡æ¬¾ç­‰ï¼‰

5.3 Environment concern

æŒ–çŸ¿å¸¦æ¥çš„ç”µåŠ›çš„æµªè´¹ï¼Œç¯å¢ƒæ±¡æŸ“ï¼Œç¡¬ä»¶æ¶ˆè€—ã€‚

entry.title: MABå­¦ä¹ ç¬”è®°
entry.content:
â€‹ Multi Armed Bandit(MAB) is a simple but very powerful framework for algorithms that make decisions over time under uncertainty. An enormous body of work has accumulated over the years.

ç®€ä»‹

â€‹

â€‹ ä¸å¤šè‡‚è€è™æœºç›¸ç±»ä¼¼çš„é—®é¢˜è¿˜æœ‰é¤é¦†é€‰æ‹©é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå½“æˆ‘ä»¬åˆ°è¾¾ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°åœ°æ–¹ä¸ä¹…ï¼Œæ˜¯æ¯æ¬¡å»æˆ‘ä»¬ç†Ÿæ‚‰çš„æœ€å¥½åƒçš„é¤é¦†è¿˜æ˜¯å»æ¢ç´¢æ–°é¤é¦†æ‰¾å¯èƒ½æ›´å¥½åƒçš„èœå“ã€‚

ä¸‹é¢æ˜¯æ‘˜è‡ªwikiçš„ä¸€æ®µæè¿°:

â€‹ In probability theory, the multi-armed bandit problem (sometimes called the K-or N-armed bandit problem) is a problem in which a fixed limited set of resources must be allocated between competing (alternative) choices in a way that maximizes their expected gain, when each choice's properties are only partially known at the time of allocation, and may become better understood as time passes or by allocating resources to the choice.

â€‹ é€šä¿—ç‚¹è®²,å½“æˆ‘ä»¬åœ¨ç©è€è™æœºæ—¶ï¼Œè€è™æœºæœ‰å¤šä¸ªæ‘‡è‡‚å¯ä¾›é€‰æ‹©ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªæ‘‡è‡‚å¯¹åº”çš„æ”¶ç›Šåˆ†å¸ƒæ˜¯å›ºå®šä½†æœªçŸ¥çš„ï¼Œç©å®¶éœ€è¦åœ¨æœ‰é™æ¬¡çš„æ¬¡æ•°ä¸‹åšå‡ºæœ€åˆé€‚çš„é€‰æ‹©ã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆæç«¯åœ°æƒ³ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬æ¯æ¬¡æ‘‡è‡‚å°±æœ‰ä¸¤ç§å€¾å‘ï¼š

  • å°è¯•æ–°çš„â€œè€è™è‡‚â€ï¼Œä¹Ÿè®¸ä¼šå¾—åˆ°æ¯”ä¹‹å‰æ›´å¥½çš„ç»“æœ(Explore)

  • åˆ©ç”¨å·²çŸ¥çš„è€è™è‡‚åšæœ€å¥½çš„é€‰æ‹©(Exploit)

ä¸‹é¢ä»‹ç»ä¸€äº›åŸºæœ¬çš„ç®—æ³•

1. Unioform Exploration

åŸºæœ¬ä»‹ç»

â€‹ è¿™ä¸ªå‡åŒ€æ¢ç´¢ç®—æ³•çš„æ€æƒ³å¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ª Explore-first çš„ç®—æ³•ã€‚é¦–å…ˆç¡®å®šå¥½Exploration Phase å’Œ Exploitation Phaseçš„å¤§å°ï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨Exploration Phaseä¸­å‡åŒ€åœ°æ¢ç´¢æ¯ä¸ªæ‘‡è‡‚ï¼Œç”¨æœŸæœ›æ¥æè¿°è¿™ä¸ªæ‘‡è‡‚å¯¹åº”çš„æ”¶ç›Šï¼Œä¹‹ååœ¨Exploitation Phaseä¸­æ ¹æ®ä¹‹å‰çš„æœ€å¤§æ”¶ç›Šé€‰æ‹©è¿›è¡Œæ¸¸æˆã€‚

â€‹ å¤§ä½“æµç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹:

  1. Exploration Phase: try each arm N times
  2. Select the arm Î±^\hat{\alpha}Î±^ with the highest reward
  3. Explotiation Phase: play arm Î±^\hat{\alpha}Î±^ in all remaining rounds

Regret analysis

â€‹ åœ¨è¿›è¡Œexploitçš„æ—¶å€™æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šç”¨ä¹‹å‰exploreå¾—åˆ°çš„æ”¶ç›Šçš„å¹³å‡å€¼Î¼Ë‰(Î±)\bar{\mu}(\alpha)Î¼Ë‰â€‹(Î±) ä½œä¸ºå¯¹çœŸå®æœŸæœ›Î¼(Î±)\mu(\alpha)Î¼(Î±)çš„ä¼°è®¡ï¼Œå¦‚æœæƒ³è¦æœ€ååˆ†æå¾—åˆ°çš„ç»“æœå‡†ç¡®æˆ‘ä»¬åº”ä½¿è¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªç»“æœä¹‹é—´çš„å·®å€¼å°½é‡å°ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨Hoeffding inequalityå¯¹å…¶è¿›è¡Œåˆ†æã€‚

â€‹ By defining the confidence radius r(Î±)=2logTNr(\alpha) = \sqrt{\frac{2logT}{N}}r(Î±)=N2logTâ€‹â€‹ , using Hoeffding inequality, we get :

Prâ¡{âˆ£Î¼Ë‰(a)âˆ’Î¼(a)âˆ£â‰¤r(a)}â‰¥1âˆ’2T4\operatorname{Pr}\{|\bar{\mu}(a)-\mu(a)| \leq r(a)\} \geq 1-\frac{2}{T^{4}} Pr{âˆ£Î¼Ë‰â€‹(a)âˆ’Î¼(a)âˆ£â‰¤r(a)}â‰¥1âˆ’T42â€‹

â€‹ æˆ‘ä»¬å®šä¹‰Î¼Ë‰(Î±)\bar{\mu}(\alpha)Î¼Ë‰â€‹(Î±) åœ¨è¿™ä¸ªèŒƒå›´å†…ä¸º clean event, åä¹‹ä¸º bad event.å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°bad eventçš„order ä¸º Tâˆ’4T^{-4}Tâˆ’4å¯ä»¥å¿½ç•¥ä¸è®¡ï¼Œåœ¨åé¢çš„æ¨å¯¼è¯æ˜ä¸­ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å§‘ä¸”ä¸è€ƒè™‘bad eventçš„å½±å“ã€‚

â€‹ åé¢çš„è¯æ˜æ¨å¯¼å°†é‡‡ç”¨è‹±æ–‡QAQã€‚

â€‹ For simplicity, let us start with the case of K = 2 arms. Consider the clean event. We will show that if we chose the worse arm, it is not so bad because the expected rewards for the two arms would be close.

â€‹ Let the best arm be \alpha^{âœ³ï¸} and suppose the algorithm chooses the other arm a \neq a^{âœ³ï¸} . This must have been because its average reward was better than that of a^{âœ³ï¸} ; in other words, \bar{\mu}(a)>\bar{\mu}\left(a^{âœ³ï¸}\right) . Since this is a clean event, we have:

Î¼(a)+r(a)â‰¥Î¼Ë‰(a)>Î¼Ë‰(aâˆ—)â‰¥Î¼(aâˆ—)âˆ’r(aâˆ—)\mu(a)+r(a) \geq \bar{\mu}(a)>\bar{\mu}\left(a^{*}\right) \geq \mu\left(a^{*}\right)-r\left(a^{*}\right) Î¼(a)+r(a)â‰¥Î¼Ë‰â€‹(a)>Î¼Ë‰â€‹(aâˆ—)â‰¥Î¼(aâˆ—)âˆ’r(aâˆ—)

â€‹ Re-arranging the terms, it follows that

Î¼(aâˆ—)âˆ’Î¼(a)â‰¤r(a)+r(aâˆ—)=O(logâ¡TN)\mu\left(a^{*}\right)-\mu(a) \leq r(a)+r\left(a^{*}\right)=O\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log T}{N}}\right) Î¼(aâˆ—)âˆ’Î¼(a)â‰¤r(a)+r(aâˆ—)=O(NlogTâ€‹â€‹)

â€‹ Thus, each round in the exploitation phase contributes at most O(logâ¡TN)O\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log T}{N}}\right)O(NlogTâ€‹â€‹) to regret. And each round in exploration trivially contributes at most 1.1 .1. We derive an upper bound on the regret, which consists of two parts: for the first N rounds of exploration, and then for the remaining T - 2N rounds of exploitation:

â€‹ Recall that we can select any value for N,N,N, as long as it is known to the algorithm before the first round. So, we can choose NNN so as to (approximately) minimize the right-hand side. Noting that the two summands are, resp., monotonically increasing and monotonically decreasing in N,N,N, we set NNN so that they are (approximately) equal. For N=T2/3(logâ¡T)1/3,N=T^{2 / 3}(\log T)^{1 / 3},N=T2/3(logT)1/3, we obtain:

R(T)â‰¤O(T2/3(logâ¡T)1/3)R(T) \leq O\left(T^{2 / 3}(\log T)^{1 / 3}\right) R(T)â‰¤O(T2/3(logT)1/3)

â€‹ To complete the proof, we have to analyze the case of the â€œbad eventâ€. Since regret can be at most T (because each round contributes at most 1), and the bad event happens with a very small probability (1/T 4), the (expected) regret from this case can be neglected. Formally,

E[R(T)]=E[R(T)âˆ£Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]Ã—Prâ¡[Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]+E[R(T)âˆ£Â badÂ eventÂ ]Ã—Prâ¡[Â badÂ eventÂ ]â‰¤E[R(T)âˆ£Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]+TÃ—O(Tâˆ’4)â‰¤O(logâ¡TÃ—T2/3)\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[R(T)] &=\mathbb{E}[R(T) \mid \text { clean event }] \times \operatorname{Pr}[\text { clean event }]+\mathbb{E}[R(T) \mid \text { bad event }] \times \operatorname{Pr}[\text { bad event }] \\ & \leq \mathbb{E}[R(T) \mid \text { clean event }]+T \times O\left(T^{-4}\right) \\ & \leq O\left(\sqrt{\log T} \times T^{2 / 3}\right) \end{aligned} E[R(T)]â€‹=E[R(T)âˆ£Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]Ã—Pr[Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]+E[R(T)âˆ£Â badÂ eventÂ ]Ã—Pr[Â badÂ eventÂ ]â‰¤E[R(T)âˆ£Â cleanÂ eventÂ ]+TÃ—O(Tâˆ’4)â‰¤O(logTâ€‹Ã—T2/3)â€‹

â€‹ This complete the proff of K=2 arms.

â€‹ For K>2K>2K>2 arms, we have to apply the union bound for (1) over the KKK arms, and then follow the same argument as above. Note that the value of TTT is greater than K,K,K, since we need to explore each arm at least once. For the final regret computation, we will need to take into account the dependence on KKK : specifically, regret accumulated in exploration phase is now upper-bounded by KN.K N .KN. Working through the proof, we obtain R(T)â‰¤NK+O(logâ¡TNÃ—T).R(T) \leq N K+O\left(\sqrt{\frac{\log T}{N}} \times T\right) .R(T)â‰¤NK+O(NlogTâ€‹â€‹Ã—T). As before, we approximately minimize it by approximately minimizing the two summands. Specifically, we plug in N=(T/K)2/3â‹…O(logâ¡T)1/3.N=(T / K)^{2 / 3} \cdot O(\log T)^{1 / 3} .N=(T/K)2/3â‹…O(logT)1/3. Completing the proof same way as in (5)(5)(5) we obtain:

Explore First Algortihm achieves regret:E[R(T)]â‰¤T2/3Ã—O(Klogâ¡T)1/3\mathbb{E}[R(T)] \leq T^{2 / 3} \times O(K \log T)^{1 / 3}E[R(T)]â‰¤T2/3Ã—O(KlogT)1/3

2 Adaptive Exploration

â€‹ Both exploration-first and epsilon-greedy have a big flaw that the exploration schedule does not depend on the history of the observed rewards. Whereas it is usually better to adapt exploration to the observed rewards. Informally, we refer to this distinction as adaptive vs non-adaptive exploration. In the remainder of this article we present two algorithms that implement adaptive exploration and achieve better regret.

â€‹ Let's start with the case of K=2K=2K=2 arms. One natural idea is to alternate them until we find that one armi s much better than the other, at which time we abandon the inferior one. But how to define "one arm is much better" exactly?

Clean evnt and confidence bounds

â€‹ Let us flesh out the idea mentioned above; this would also set up the stage for some other algorithms. Fix round t.t .t. Let nt(a)n_{t}(a)ntâ€‹(a) be the number of samples from armâ¡a\operatorname{arm} aarma in round 1,2,â€¦,t.Î¼Ë‰t(a)1,2, \ldots, t . \bar{\mu}_{t}(a)1,2,â€¦,t.Î¼Ë‰â€‹tâ€‹(a) be the average reward of arm aaa so far. We would like to use Hoeffding Inequality to derive

entry.title: KKTä¸CQ
entry.content:
KKTå·²ç»æˆä¸ºäº†å‡ ä¹æ‰€æœ‰çš„CS ã€MATå­¦ç”Ÿéƒ½ç»•ä¸å¼€çš„çŸ¥è¯†ã€å·¥å…·ã€‚æµ…å†™ä¸€ä¸‹è‡ªå·±åœ¨å‡ å¹´çš„å­¦ä¹ ä¸­å¯¹KKTå’ŒCQçš„ä¸€äº›ç†è§£ï¼Œæ–¹ä¾¿è‡ªå·±æ—¥åå¤ä¹ ã€‚

1 Unconstrained Problem

è¿™ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†æ˜¯non-linear programming çš„åŸºç¡€ï¼Œè¿™ä¸æ˜¯æœ¬ç¯‡æ–‡ç« æƒ³è¦è®¨è®ºçš„é‡ç‚¹ï¼Œæ—¥åå¯èƒ½ä¼šç»§ç»­åšä¸€æ¬¡æ€»ç»“ã€‚å¯¹äºunconstrainedçš„é—®é¢˜å¤§ä½“æœ‰2ä¸ªè§£æ³•ï¼š

  1. Gradient Descent (1é˜¶çš„ç®—æ³•)
  2. Newton's method / Quasi Neston's methodï¼ˆ2é˜¶çš„ç®—æ³•ï¼‰

Unconstrained Problem æ˜¯è§£å†³constrained problemçš„åŸºç¡€ã€‚barrier methodã€penalty method ç­‰éƒ½æ˜¯å°†constrains æ”¾åˆ°objective functionä¹‹ä¸Šï¼Œé€šè¿‡è§£å†³unconstrained problemæ¥å¾—åˆ°è§£ï¼ˆè¿™äº›è§£æ³•é€šå¸¸éƒ½å¯ä»¥ä¸KKT point \ Duality ç­‰ç»“æœç›¸è”ç³»ï¼‰

2 Constrained Problem and KKT condition

å¯¹äºé—®é¢˜ï¼š

minâ¡xâˆˆRnf(x)Â s.t.Â g(x)â‰¤0,h(x)=0,\min _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}} f(x) \text { s.t. } g(x) \leq 0, \quad h(x)=0, xâˆˆRnminâ€‹f(x)Â s.t.Â g(x)â‰¤0,h(x)=0,

è‹¥x' æ˜¯è¯¥é—®é¢˜çš„local solutionï¼Œä¸”åœ¨x'å¤„æ»¡è¶³ä¸€ç§CQï¼Œåˆ™åœ¨x'å¤„å¿…å­˜åœ¨ä»¥ä¸‹æ–¹ç¨‹çš„ä¸€ç»„è§£ï¼š

1st Order Karush-Kuhn-Tucker conditions (1é˜¶KKT conditionsï¼‰

{Â (i)Â âˆ‡f(xâˆ—)+âˆ‡g(xâˆ—)Î»âˆ—+âˆ‡h(xâˆ—)Î¼âˆ—=0Â (multiplierÂ rule)Â Â (ii)Â h(xâˆ—)=0Â (iii)Â Î»âˆ—â‰¥0,g(xâˆ—)â‰¤0,(Î»âˆ—)âŠ¤g(xâˆ—)=0Â (complementarityÂ conditions).Â \left\{\begin{array}{l} \text { (i) } \nabla f\left(x^{*}\right)+\nabla g\left(x^{*}\right) \lambda^{*}+\nabla h\left(x^{*}\right) \mu^{*}=0 \quad \text { (multiplier rule) } \\ \text { (ii) } h\left(x^{*}\right)=0 \\ \text { (iii) } \lambda^{*} \geq 0, \quad g\left(x^{*}\right) \leq 0, \quad\left(\lambda^{*}\right)^{\top} g\left(x^{*}\right)=0 \quad \text { (complementarity conditions). } \end{array}\right. â©âªâ¨âªâ§â€‹Â (i)Â âˆ‡f(xâˆ—)+âˆ‡g(xâˆ—)Î»âˆ—+âˆ‡h(xâˆ—)Î¼âˆ—=0Â (multiplierÂ rule)Â Â (ii)Â h(xâˆ—)=0Â (iii)Â Î»âˆ—â‰¥0,g(xâˆ—)â‰¤0,(Î»âˆ—)âŠ¤g(xâˆ—)=0Â (complementarityÂ conditions).Â â€‹

KKT conditioné€šè¿‡ Farkas Lemmaè¯æ˜çš„ï¼Œè¿™ä¸€è¯æ˜å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒberserkasçš„æ•™ç§‘ä¹¦ã€‚

ä»ä»¥ä¸Šçš„æè¿°ä¸­æˆ‘ä»¬å†å¼ºè°ƒä¸‹è¿™ä¸ªå®šç†è¯´æè¿°çš„äº‹æƒ…ï¼Œè‹¥åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªx*å¤„æ»¡è¶³ä¸€ç§â€œCconstrained Qualificationâ€ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå°±ä¸€å®šæœ‰æ»¡è¶³KKTçš„è§£ã€‚ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è¯´ï¼Œåœ¨xå¤„è‹¥æœ‰CQï¼Œåˆ™KKTæ˜¯å¿…è¦æ¡ä»¶ã€‚

é‚£ä¹ˆæˆ‘ä»¬ç°åœ¨éœ€è¦é‡æ–°äº†è§£ä¸‹ï¼š

ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯CQï¼Ÿ

3 Constrained Qualification

è‹¥è¦äº†è§£constrained qualification éœ€è¦å…ˆäº†è§£â€œconeâ€ï¼š

Feasible set and Active Constrain

Definition 1:Feasible Set and Active Constraints The set

X:={xâˆˆRn:g(x)â‰¤0,h(x)=0}X:=\left\{x \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: g(x) \leq 0, h(x)=0\right\} X:={xâˆˆRn:g(x)â‰¤0,h(x)=0}

is called feasible set of the problem (1). A point xâˆˆRnx \in \mathbb{R}^{n}xâˆˆRn is called feasible if we have xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆX. For a feasible point xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆX, we define the index set of the active constraints A(x)\mathcal{A}(x)A(x) and the index set of the inactive constraints I(x)\mathcal{I}(x)I(x) as follows:

A(x):={iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,m}:gi(x)=0}I(x):={1,â€¦,m}\A(x)={iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,m}:gi(x)<0}\begin{aligned} \mathcal{A}(x) &:=\left\{i \in\{1, \ldots, m\}: g_{i}(x)=0\right\} \\ \mathcal{I}(x) &:=\{1, \ldots, m\} \backslash \mathcal{A}(x)=\left\{i \in\{1, \ldots, m\}: g_{i}(x)<0\right\} \end{aligned} A(x)I(x)â€‹:={iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,m}:giâ€‹(x)=0}:={1,â€¦,m}\A(x)={iâˆˆ{1,â€¦,m}:giâ€‹(x)<0}â€‹

Definition 2: Tangent Cone Let XâŠ‚RnX \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}XâŠ‚Rn be a nonempty set. The tangent cone (or Bouligand cone) of XXX at a point xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆX is given by

TX(x):={dâˆˆRn:âˆƒ(Î·k)kâˆˆR++,(xk)kâˆˆXÂ suchÂ thatÂ xkâ†’x,Î·k(xkâˆ’x)â†’d}T_{X}(x):=\left\{d \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: \exists\left(\eta_{k}\right)_{k} \in \mathbb{R}_{++},\left(x^{k}\right)_{k} \in X \text { such that } x^{k} \rightarrow x, \quad \eta_{k}\left(x^{k}-x\right) \rightarrow d\right\} TXâ€‹(x):={dâˆˆRn:âˆƒ(Î·kâ€‹)kâ€‹âˆˆR++â€‹,(xk)kâ€‹âˆˆXÂ suchÂ thatÂ xkâ†’x,Î·kâ€‹(xkâˆ’x)â†’d}

Definition 3: Linealized Tangent Cone

The set

Tâ„“(g,h,x):={dâˆˆRn:âˆ‡gi(x)âŠ¤dâ‰¤0âˆ€iâˆˆA(x),âˆ‡h(x)âŠ¤d=0}T_{\ell}(g, h, x):=\left\{d \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: \nabla g_{i}(x)^{\top} d \leq 0 \forall i \in \mathcal{A}(x), \quad \nabla h(x)^{\top} d=0\right\} Tâ„“â€‹(g,h,x):={dâˆˆRn:âˆ‡giâ€‹(x)âŠ¤dâ‰¤0âˆ€iâˆˆA(x),âˆ‡h(x)âŠ¤d=0}

is called the linearized tangent cone at xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆX

å‡ ä¸ªCQï¼š

ACQ

Tâ„“(g,h,x)=TX(x)T_{\ell}(g, h, x)=T_{X}(x) Tâ„“â€‹(g,h,x)=TXâ€‹(x)

GCQ

TX(xâˆ—)âˆ˜=Tâ„“(g,h,xâˆ—)âˆ˜whereKâˆ˜:={vâˆˆRn:vâŠ¤dâ‰¤0âˆ€dâˆˆK}T_{X}\left(x^{*}\right)^{\circ}=T_{\ell}\left(g, h, x^{*}\right)^{\circ}\\ \text{where} \\ K^{\circ}:=\left\{v \in \mathbb{R}^{n}: v^{\top} d \leq 0 \quad \forall d \in K\right\} TXâ€‹(xâˆ—)âˆ˜=Tâ„“â€‹(g,h,xâˆ—)âˆ˜whereKâˆ˜:={vâˆˆRn:vâŠ¤dâ‰¤0âˆ€dâˆˆK}

Definition 4: Constraint Qualification Let xâˆˆXx \in XxâˆˆX be given. A condition that implies the (GCQ) is called Constraint Qualification (CQ) for xxx.

entry.title: Online Learning(1) Intro
entry.content:
å¼€å‘online learning and banditsï¼Œä¸€ç›´æƒ³ç€ç³»ç»Ÿåœ°å­¦ä¹ ä¸‹ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨2022 summeräº‰å–æ‹¿ä¸‹ã€‚ğŸ¤¤ğŸ¤¤ğŸ¤¤

Basic Setting

A bandit problem is a sequential game between a learner and an environment.

The game is played over nnn rounds, where nnn is a positive natural number called the horizon. In each round tâˆˆnt \in ntâˆˆn, the learner first chooses an action AtA_tAtâ€‹ from a given set A\mathcal{A}A, and the environment then reveals a reward XtâˆˆRX_t \in \mathbb{R}Xtâ€‹âˆˆR.

The learner cannot peek into the future when choosing their actions. The action AtA_tAtâ€‹ should only depend on the history $$H_{t-1} = \left(A_{1}, X_{1}, \ldots, A_{t-1}, X_{t-1}\right)$$.

Regret

DEFINITION : The regret of the learner relative to a policy Ï€\piÏ€ (not necessarily that followed by the learner) is the difference between the total expected reward using policy Ï€\piÏ€ for nnn rounds and the total expected reward collected by the learner over nnn rounds. The regret relative to a set of policies Î \PiÎ  is the maximum regret relative to any policy Ï€âˆˆÎ \pi \in \PiÏ€âˆˆÎ  in the set.

The set Î \PiÎ  is often called the competitor class. ( ä¸Î \PiÎ  ä¸­çš„strategy å¯¹æŠ—)

Regret measures the performance of the learner relative to the best policy in the competitor class.

Example:

Suppose the action set is $$\mathcal{A}={1,2, \ldots, k}$$. An environment is called a stochastic Bernoulli bandit if the reward $$X_{t} \in{0,1}$$ is binary valued and there exists a vector $$\mu \in[0,1]^{k}$$ such that the probability that $$X_{t}=1$$ given the learner chose action $$A_{t}=a$$ is $$\mu_{a}$$. The class of stochastic Bernoulli bandits is the set of all such bandits, which are characterised by their mean vectors. If you knew the mean vector associated with the environment, then the optimal policy is to play the fixed action $$a^{*}=\operatorname{argmax}{a \in \mathcal{A}} \mu{a}$$. This means that for this problem the natural competitor class is the set of kkk constant polices $$\Pi=\left{\pi_{1}, \ldots, \pi_{k}\right}$$, where $$\pi_{i}$$ chooses action iii in every round. The regret over nnn rounds becomes

Rn=nmaxâ¡aâˆˆAÎ¼aâˆ’E[âˆ‘t=1nXt]R_{n}=n \max _{a \in \mathcal{A}} \mu_{a}-\mathbb{E}\left[\sum_{t=1}^{n} X_{t}\right] Rnâ€‹=naâˆˆAmaxâ€‹Î¼aâ€‹âˆ’E[t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Xtâ€‹]

Asymptotic analysis of regret

A good learner achieves sublinear regret. This means that $$R_n =o(n)$$ or $$\lim {n \rightarrow \infty} R{n} / n=0$$. The interesting question is under what circumstances is $$R_{n}=O(\sqrt{n}) \text { or } R_{n}=O(\log (n)) $$?

Different settings:

Stochastic Stationary Bandits

A simple problem setting is that of stochastic stationary bandits. In this case the environment is restricted to generate the reward in response to each action from a distribution that is specific to that action and independent of the previous action choices and rewards.

Xt=âŸ¨a,Î¸âŸ©+Î·tX_{t}=\langle a, \theta\rangle+\eta_{t} Xtâ€‹=âŸ¨a,Î¸âŸ©+Î·tâ€‹

Adversarial bandits

An extreme idea is to drop all assumptions on how the rewards are generated, except that they are chosen without knowledge of the learnerâ€™s actions and lie in a bounded set.

The learner is not expected to find the best sequence of actions, which may be like finding a needle in a haystack. Instead, we usually choose Î  to be the set of constant policies and demand that the learner is not much worse than any of these. By defining the regret in this way, the stationarity assumption is transported into the definition of regret rather than constraining the environment.

Reinforcement Learning

åœ¨ä¸€èˆ¬çš„é—®é¢˜ä¸­è€ƒè™‘ learnerâ€™s available choices and rewards tomorrow are not affected by their decisions today. ä½†RL è€ƒè™‘long term profit

Partial Monitoring

The setting where the reward is not observed is called partial monitoring.

Application

  • A/B Testing

The designers of a company website are trying to decide whether the â€˜buy it nowâ€™ button should be placed at the top of the product page or at the bottom.

One way to apply bandits to this problem is to view the two versions of the site as actions. Each time t a user makes a request, a bandit algorithm is used to choose an action AtâˆˆA=[SiteA,SiteB]A_t \in \mathcal{A} = [Site_A, Site_B]Atâ€‹âˆˆA=[SiteAâ€‹,SiteBâ€‹], and the reward is Xt=1X_t = 1Xtâ€‹=1 if the user purchases the product and Xt=0X_t = 0Xtâ€‹=0 otherwise.

  • Advert Placement

    In advert placement, each round corresponds to a user visiting a website, and the set of actions A\mathcal{A}A is the set of all available adverts. One could treat this as a standard multi-armed bandit problem, where in each round a policy chooses $$A_{t} \in \mathcal{A}$$, and the reward is $$X_{t}=1$$ if the user clicked on the advert and $$X_{t}=0$$

  • Dynamic Pricing

    Users arrive sequentially, and the learner sets the price.

    • (a) the learner never actually observes the valuation of the product, only the binary signal that the price was too low/too high, and
    • (b) there is a monotonicity structure in the pricing. If a user purchased an item priced at 10, then they would surely purchase it for 5, but whether or not it would sell when priced at 11$ is uncertain.

  • Network Routing

Another problem with an interesting structure is network routing, where the learner tries to direct internet traffic through the shortest path on a network. In each round the learner receives the start/end destinations for a packet of data. The set of actions is the set of all paths starting and ending at the appropriate points on some known graph.

  • Waiting Problems

    å…¬äº¤è½¦æ¥çš„æ—¶é—´ã€é€šè¡Œæ—¶é—´ä¸ç¡®å®šï¼Œä½†å¦‚æœåä¸Šäº†å°±æ—¶é—´å¾ˆçŸ­ã€‚æ­¥è¡Œæ—¶é—´é•¿ï¼Œä½†ç”¨æ—¶ç¡®å®šã€‚ï¼ˆLearn CDF of uncertain eventï¼‰

    åº”è¯¥ç­‰å¤šä¹…å…¬è½¦åå†³å®šæ­¥è¡Œï¼Ÿ

  • Resource Allocation

  • Recommendation(ç±»ä¼¼å¹¿å‘Šé—®é¢˜ï¼Œä¸è¿‡é—®é¢˜æ›´å¤æ‚)

    Netflix has to decide which movies to recommend to customers.

    The reward can be measured as some function of (a) whether or not you watched a movie and (b) whether or not you rated it positively.

  • Tree Search (?)

entry.title: Online Learning 3 ETC Algorithm
entry.content:
Explore Then Commit (ETC) Algorithm

ç®—æ³•æè¿°ï¼š

å¤§ä½“æƒ³æ³•ä¸ºå…ˆè¿›è¡Œexplore phase å°è¯•å¾ˆå¤šçš„armï¼Œç„¶ååœ¨commit phase ä¸­åªä½¿ç”¨ä¹‹å‰å‘ç°çš„æœ€å¥½çš„armã€‚

Formalï¼š

Input: mmm In round t, pull

At={t(Â modÂ k)+1Â ifÂ tâ©½mkargmaxâ¡Î¼^i(mk)Â ifÂ t>mkA_{t}= \begin{cases}t (\text{ mod } k)+1 & \text { if } t \leqslant m k \\ \operatorname{argmax}\quad \widehat{\mu}_{i}(m k) & \text { if } t>m k\end{cases} Atâ€‹={t(Â modÂ k)+1argmaxÎ¼â€‹iâ€‹(mk)â€‹Â ifÂ tâ©½mkÂ ifÂ t>mkâ€‹

Regret Analysis

å®šä¹‰ä¸€äº›notationï¼š

Î¼^i(t)=1Ti(t)âˆ‘s=1t1(As=i)XsTi(t)=âˆ‘s=1t1(As=i)Î”i=uâˆ—âˆ’Î¼iÂ (å‡è®¾armÂ 1Â æ˜¯optimal)\begin{aligned}\hat{\mu}_{i}(t)&=\frac{1}{T_{i}(t)} \sum_{s=1}^{t} \mathcal{1}(A_{s}=i) X_{s} \\T_{i}(t)&=\sum_{s=1}^{t} \mathcal{1}(A_{s}=i)\\\Delta_{i}&=u^{*}-\mu_{i}\text{ (å‡è®¾arm 1 æ˜¯optimal)}\end{aligned} Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(t)Tiâ€‹(t)Î”iâ€‹â€‹=Tiâ€‹(t)1â€‹s=1âˆ‘tâ€‹1(Asâ€‹=i)Xsâ€‹=s=1âˆ‘tâ€‹1(Asâ€‹=i)=uâˆ—âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹Â (å‡è®¾armÂ 1Â æ˜¯optimal)â€‹

Step 1ï¼šå¯¹äºç»™å®šçš„kï¼Œæ‰¾å‡ºregret çš„bound

åˆ†è§£ä¸€ä¸‹regret

regret = æ¯ä¸ªarmæ‹‰çš„æ¬¡æ•°* æ¯ä¸ªarm å¯¹åº”çš„regret

Rn=nÎ¼âˆ’E[âˆ‘t=1nÎ¼At]=âˆ‘t=1nE[Î¼âˆ’Î¼At]=âˆ‘i=1KÎ”iE[Ti(n)]R_{n}=n \mu^{}-E[\sum_{t=1}^{n} \mu_{A_{t}}]=\sum_{t=1}^{n} E[\mu^{}-\mu_{A_{t}}] = \sum_{i=1}^{K} \Delta_{i} E[T_{i}(n)]Rnâ€‹=nÎ¼âˆ’E[âˆ‘t=1nâ€‹Î¼Atâ€‹â€‹]=âˆ‘t=1nâ€‹E[Î¼âˆ’Î¼Atâ€‹â€‹]=âˆ‘i=1Kâ€‹Î”iâ€‹E[Tiâ€‹(n)]

æ¯ä¸ªarmè¢«æ‹‰çš„æ¬¡æ•°

E[Ti(n)]=m+(nâˆ’mk)P(Amk+1=i)=m+(nâˆ’mk)P(Î¼^i(mk)â©¾maxâ¡jâ‰ iÎ¼^j(mk))\begin{aligned}E[T_{i}(n)] &=m+(n-m k) P(A_{m k+1}=i) \\&=m+(n-m k) P(\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k) \geqslant \max _{j \neq i} \hat{\mu}_{j}(m k))\end{aligned} E[Tiâ€‹(n)]â€‹=m+(nâˆ’mk)P(Amk+1â€‹=i)=m+(nâˆ’mk)P(Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(mk)â©¾jî€ =imaxâ€‹Î¼^â€‹jâ€‹(mk))â€‹

\begin{align}&P(\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k) \geqslant \max _{j \neq i} \hat{\mu}_{j}(m k))\\ &\leq P(\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k) \geqslant \hat{\mu}_{1}(m k))\text{ ç¬¬ä¸€æ­¥æ”¾ç¼©ï¼Œåªå…³æ³¨è·Ÿæœ€ä¼˜armç›¸æ¯”}\\&\leq.P(\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k)-\mu_{i})-(\hat{\mu}_{1}(m k)-\mu_{1}) \geqslant \mu_{1}-\mu_{i})\end{align}

Î¼^i(mk)\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k)Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(mk)ï¼š ç”±äºå‡è®¾æ¯ä¸ªxix_ixiâ€‹ æ˜¯1-subgaussianï¼ŒÎ¼^i(mk)\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k)Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(mk)æ˜¯1/m-subgaussian

(Î¼^i(mk)âˆ’Î¼i)âˆ’(Î¼^1(mk)âˆ’Î¼1)(\hat{\mu}_{i}(m k)-\mu_{i})-(\hat{\mu}_{1}(m k)-\mu_{1})(Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(mk)âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹)âˆ’(Î¼^â€‹1â€‹(mk)âˆ’Î¼1â€‹) : (1/m+1/m)-subgaussian

å› æ­¤ï¼šï½â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Î”i22(.2m)2.)=expâ¡(âˆ’m4Î”i2)ï½\leq\exp (-\frac{\Delta_{i}^{2}}{2(\sqrt{.\frac{2}{m})^{2}}.})=\exp (-\frac{m}{4} \Delta_{i}^{2})ï½â‰¤exp(âˆ’2(.m2â€‹)2â€‹.Î”i2â€‹â€‹)=exp(âˆ’4mâ€‹Î”i2â€‹)

Rnâ©½âˆ‘i=1kÎ”i(m+(nâˆ’mk)expâ¡(âˆ’m4Î”i2))â©½kÎ”Ë‰(m+(nâˆ’mk)expâ¡(âˆ’m4Î”Ë‰2))\begin{aligned}&R_{n} \leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{k} \Delta_{i}(m+(n-m k) \exp (-\frac{m}{4} \Delta_{i}^{2})) \\&\leqslant k \bar{\Delta}(m+(n-m k) \exp (-\frac{m}{4} \bar{\Delta}^{2})) \end{aligned} â€‹Rnâ€‹â©½i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹Î”iâ€‹(m+(nâˆ’mk)exp(âˆ’4mâ€‹Î”i2â€‹))â©½kÎ”Ë‰(m+(nâˆ’mk)exp(âˆ’4mâ€‹Î”Ë‰2))â€‹

æœ€åæ±‚å¯¼å–optimalçš„kå°±å¯ä»¥äº†

For Example

k=2Rnâ©½mÎ”+nÎ”expâ¡(âˆ’m4Î”2)k=2 \quad R_{n} \leqslant m \Delta+n \Delta \exp (-\frac{m}{4} \Delta^{2})k=2Rnâ€‹â©½mÎ”+nÎ”exp(âˆ’4mâ€‹Î”2)

Given Î”,m\Delta, mÎ”,m minimizes {mÎ”+Î”expâ¡(âˆ’m4Î”2)}\{m \Delta+\Delta \exp (-\frac{m}{4} \Delta^{2})\}{mÎ”+Î”exp(âˆ’4mâ€‹Î”2)}

which is m=âŒˆ4Î”2logâ¡(nÎ”24)âŒ‰m=\lceil\frac{4}{\Delta^{2}} \log (\frac{n \Delta^{2}}{4})\rceilm=âŒˆÎ”24â€‹log(4nÎ”2â€‹)âŒ‰

and for this choice the regret is bounded by Rnâ‰¤Î”+4Î”(1+logâ¡(nÎ”24))R_{n} \leq \Delta+\frac{4}{\Delta}(1+\log (\frac{n \Delta^{2}}{4}))Rnâ€‹â‰¤Î”+Î”4â€‹(1+log(4nÎ”2â€‹))

æ­¤æ—¶å¾—åˆ°çš„bound ç§°ä¸ºï¼š instance-dependent

entry.title: Online Learning 2 SB and Concentration Inequality
entry.content:
The goal of this chapter is to formally introduce stochastic bandits. The model introduced here provides the foundation for the remaining chapters that treat stochastic bandits.

Core Assumptions

A stochastic bandit is a collection of distributions $$\nu=\left(P_{a}: a \in \mathcal{A}\right)$$, where A\mathcal{A}A is the set of available actions. The learner and the environment interact sequentially over n rounds.

The interactions between learner and environment induce a probability measure on outcomes: A1,X1,A2,X2â€¦An,XnA_1,X_1,A_2,X_2 \dots A_n,X_nA1â€‹,X1â€‹,A2â€‹,X2â€‹â€¦Anâ€‹,Xnâ€‹

2 main assumptions of Stochastic Bandits:

(a) The conditional distribution of reward XtX_tXtâ€‹ given A1,X1,â€¦,Atâˆ’1,Xtâˆ’1,AtA_1, X_1, \dots, A_{t-1}, X_{t-1}, A_{t}A1â€‹,X1â€‹,â€¦,Atâˆ’1â€‹,Xtâˆ’1â€‹,Atâ€‹ is PAtP_{A_{t}}PAtâ€‹â€‹, which captures the intuition that the environment samples XtX_tXtâ€‹ from PAtP_{A_{t}}PAtâ€‹â€‹ in round t.t .t.

reward XtX_tXtâ€‹ åªå’Œ AtA_tAtâ€‹ æœ‰å…³

(b) The conditional law of action AtA_{t}Atâ€‹ given A1,X1,â€¦,Atâˆ’1,Xtâˆ’1A_{1}, X_{1}, \ldots, A_{t-1}, X_{t-1}A1â€‹,X1â€‹,â€¦,Atâˆ’1â€‹,Xtâˆ’1â€‹ is Ï€t(â‹…âˆ£A1,X1,â€¦,Atâˆ’1,Xtâˆ’1)\pi_{t}\left(\cdot \mid A_{1}, X_{1}, \ldots, A_{t-1}, X_{t-1}\right)Ï€tâ€‹(â‹…âˆ£A1â€‹,X1â€‹,â€¦,Atâˆ’1â€‹,Xtâˆ’1â€‹), where Ï€1,Ï€2,â€¦\pi_{1}, \pi_{2}, \ldotsÏ€1â€‹,Ï€2â€‹,â€¦ is a sequence of probability kernels that characterise the learner. The most important element of this assumption is the intuitive fact that the learner cannot use the future observations in current decisions.

å†³ç­–è€…åœ¨æ¯ä¸€æœŸçš„å†³ç­–åªåŸºäºHistoryï¼Œä¸è€ƒè™‘futureï¼Œä¹Ÿå³ï¼š

Ï€t:Htâˆ’1â†’A\pi_t : H_{t-1} \rightarrow \mathcal{A} Ï€tâ€‹:Htâˆ’1â€‹â†’A

Main learning objectives:

Learnerçš„ç›®æ ‡æ˜¯maximize $$S_{n}=\sum_{t=1}^{n} X_{t}$$

  • å…³äºnnnçš„å–å€¼ï¼Œlearnerå¹¶ä¸èƒ½æå‰çŸ¥é“è¦ç©å‡ è½®åšå¼ˆ
  • Reward æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªéšæœºé‡ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦å®šä¹‰ä¸€ä¸ªmeasureæ¥è¡¡é‡rewardçš„å¥½å
  • Learner å¹¶ä¸çŸ¥é“æ¯ä¸ªarmçœŸå®çš„reward distribution

Environment

Environment /Instance: $$\quad \nu=\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{k}\right) \in \varepsilon$$

The set E\mathcal{E}E is called environment class.

environment æè¿°äº†æ¯ä¸ªarmèƒŒåå¯¹åº”çš„åˆ†å¸ƒçš„â€œé€‰æ‹©èŒƒå›´â€

Example:

ÎµkB={(Î¼1,â€¦,Î¼k)âˆˆ[0,1]k,Piâˆ¼Â BernoullÂ (Î¼i)}\varepsilon_{k}^{B}=\left\{\left(\mu_{1}, \ldots, \mu_{k}\right) \in[0,1]^{k}, P_{i} \sim \text { Bernoull }\left(\mu_{i}\right)\right\} ÎµkBâ€‹={(Î¼1â€‹,â€¦,Î¼kâ€‹)âˆˆ[0,1]k,Piâ€‹âˆ¼Â BernoullÂ (Î¼iâ€‹)}

Regret

Rn(Î½,Ï€)=nÎ¼(Î½)âˆ—âˆ’E[âˆ‘t=1nÎ¼At]R_{n}(\nu, \pi)=n \mu_{(\nu)}^{*}-E\left[\sum_{t=1}^{n} \mu_{A_{t}}\right] Rnâ€‹(Î½,Ï€)=nÎ¼(Î½)âˆ—â€‹âˆ’E[t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Î¼Atâ€‹â€‹]

minâ¡Ï€âˆˆÎµmaxâ¡vâˆˆÎµRn(v,Ï€)\min _{\pi \in \varepsilon} \max {v \in \varepsilon} \quad R_{n}(v, \pi) Ï€âˆˆÎµminâ€‹maxvâˆˆÎµRnâ€‹(v,Ï€)

Concentration Inequality

concentration inequality åœ¨è¯æ˜regretæ”¶æ•›æ€§ä¸Šéå¸¸é‡è¦ï¼Œåœ¨è¿™é‡Œè¿›è¡Œä»‹ç»ã€‚

Theorem 1 Law of large number:

LLN è¯´çš„æ˜¯ï¼š

Asnâ†’âˆ1n(X1+â‹¯+Xn)â†’XiË‰\text{As}\quad n \rightarrow \infty\quad \frac{1}{n}\left(X_{1}+\cdots+X_{n}\right) \rightarrow \bar{X_i} Asnâ†’âˆn1â€‹(X1â€‹+â‹¯+Xnâ€‹)â†’Xiâ€‹Ë‰â€‹

ä»…ä»…åªè¯´æ˜äº†ä¸€ä¸ªâ€œæ”¶æ•›æ€§â€

Theorem 2 Central limit theorem:

CLT: X1,â€¦,XnX_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}X1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹ iid, with mean Î¼varâ¡Ïƒ2\mu \operatorname{var} \sigma^{2}Î¼varÏƒ2

n(xË‰nâˆ’Î¼)Ïƒâ†’dN(0,1)\sqrt{n} \frac{\left(\bar{x}_{n}-\mu\right)}{\sigma} \stackrel{d}{\rightarrow} N(0,1) nâ€‹Ïƒ(xË‰nâ€‹âˆ’Î¼)â€‹â†’dN(0,1)

CLT æ›´è¿‘ä¸€æ­¥è¯´æ˜äº†â€œæ”¶æ•›é€Ÿç‡â€ä¸ºn\sqrt{n}nâ€‹

Theorem 3 Concentration inequality:

ä¹‹å‰çš„2ä¸ªtheoremè¯´çš„éƒ½æ˜¯å½“nè¶‹äºæ— ç©·æ—¶çš„æ”¶æ•›æ€§ã€‚è€Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦çš„å·¥å…·æ˜¯ï¼šâ€œåœ¨ä¸­å¿ƒé™„è¿‘çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåŒºé—´ä¸Šçš„æ¦‚ç‡æ˜¯å¤šå°‘â€ã€‚è§£å†³è¿™ä¸€é—®é¢˜çš„å·¥å…·å°±æ˜¯ Concentration Inequalityã€‚å…¶å½¢å¦‚ï¼š

P(âˆ£xË‰nâˆ’Î¼âˆ£â©¾Îµn)â©½ÏƒnP\left(\left|\bar{x}_{n}-\mu\right| \geqslant \varepsilon_{n}\right) \leqslant \sigma_{n} P(âˆ£xË‰nâ€‹âˆ’Î¼âˆ£â©¾Îµnâ€‹)â©½Ïƒnâ€‹

Thm 1 Markov Inequality

P(âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Îµ)â©½E[âˆ£xâˆ£]ÎµP(|x| \geq \varepsilon) \leqslant \frac{ E[|x|]}{\varepsilon} P(âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Îµ)â©½ÎµE[âˆ£xâˆ£]â€‹

Proof:

E[âˆ£xâˆ£]=E[âˆ£xâˆ£1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¤Ïµ]+E[âˆ£xâˆ£1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµ]â‰¥0+E[Ïµ1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµ]=ÏµP(âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµ)\begin{aligned} E[|x|] &=E\left[|x| \mathcal{1}_{|x| \leq\epsilon}\right]+E\left[|x| \mathcal{1}_{|x| \geq\epsilon}\right]\\ &\geq 0 + E\left[\epsilon \mathcal{1}_{|x| \geq\epsilon}\right]\\ &=\epsilon P(|x| \geq \epsilon) \end{aligned} E[âˆ£xâˆ£]â€‹=E[âˆ£xâˆ£1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¤Ïµâ€‹]+E[âˆ£xâˆ£1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµâ€‹]â‰¥0+E[Ïµ1âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµâ€‹]=ÏµP(âˆ£xâˆ£â‰¥Ïµ)â€‹

Thm 2 Chebychev Inequality

P(âˆ£Xâˆ’E[x]âˆ£â©¾Îµ)â‰¤Varâ¡(x)Îµ2P(|X-E[x]| \geqslant \varepsilon) \leq \frac{\operatorname{Var}(x)}{\varepsilon^{2}} P(âˆ£Xâˆ’E[x]âˆ£â©¾Îµ)â‰¤Îµ2Var(x)â€‹

ä½†æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šå‘ç°ï¼Œç”¨chebychevç¡®å®šçš„boundå¾€å¾€å¤ªå®½äº†ï¼Œä»¥å¦‚ä¸‹caseä¸ºä¾‹ï¼š

Let

x=xnË‰Varâ¡(XË‰n)=1nVarâ¡(X1)x=\bar{x_n} \quad \operatorname{Var}\left(\bar{X}_{n}\right)=\frac{1}{n} \operatorname{Var}\left(X_{1}\right) x=xnâ€‹Ë‰â€‹Var(XË‰nâ€‹)=n1â€‹Var(X1â€‹)

åˆ‡æ¯”é›ªå¤«å¾—åˆ°çš„boundï¼š

P(âˆ£XË‰nâˆ’Î¼âˆ£>Îµ)â‰¤1nÎµ2Varâ¡(X1)P\left(\left|\bar{X}_{n}-\mu\right|>\varepsilon\right) \leq \frac{1}{n \varepsilon^{2}} \operatorname{Var}\left(X_{1}\right) P(âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹XË‰nâ€‹âˆ’Î¼âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹>Îµ)â‰¤nÎµ21â€‹Var(X1â€‹)

ç„¶è€Œå®é™…ä¸Šfor X1âˆ¼N(0,1)X_1 \sim N(0,1)X1â€‹âˆ¼N(0,1) æˆ‘ä»¬ç§¯åˆ†ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼š

P(x1â©¾Îµ)=âˆ«Îµ+âˆ12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’x22)dxâ‰¤1Îµ2Ï€âˆ«Îµ+âˆxexpâ¡(âˆ’x22)dx=1Ïµ2Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’Îµ22)\begin{aligned}P\left(x_{1} \geqslant \varepsilon\right) &=\int_{\varepsilon}^{+\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \exp \left(-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right) d x \\& \leq \frac{1}{\varepsilon \sqrt{2 \pi}} \int_{\varepsilon}^{+\infty} x \exp \left(-\frac{x^{2}}{2}\right) d x \\&=\frac{1}{\epsilon\sqrt{2 \pi} } \operatorname{exp}\left(-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2}\right)\end{aligned} P(x1â€‹â©¾Îµ)â€‹=âˆ«Îµ+âˆâ€‹2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2x2â€‹)dxâ‰¤Îµ2Ï€â€‹1â€‹âˆ«Îµ+âˆâ€‹xexp(âˆ’2x2â€‹)dx=Ïµ2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2Îµ2â€‹)â€‹

å¯¹äºXnË‰âˆ¼N(0,1/n)\bar{X_n}\sim N(0,1/n)Xnâ€‹Ë‰â€‹âˆ¼N(0,1/n)

P(XnË‰<Ïµ)â‰¤1Ïµ2Ï€nexpâ¡(âˆ’nÎµ22)âˆ¼exp(âˆ’cn)P(\bar{X_n}<\epsilon)\leq \frac{1}{\epsilon\sqrt{2 \pi n } } \operatorname{exp}(-\frac{n\varepsilon^{2}}{2})\sim \text{exp}(-cn) P(Xnâ€‹Ë‰â€‹<Ïµ)â‰¤Ïµ2Ï€nâ€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2nÎµ2â€‹)âˆ¼exp(âˆ’cn)

æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªexponentialçš„é€Ÿç‡ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åˆ‡æ¯”é›ªå¤«çš„1/nçš„bound

Definitionï¼š Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-subgaussian

if for all Î»âˆˆR\lambda \in RÎ»âˆˆR we have:

E[expâ¡(Î»x)]â©½expâ¡(Î»2Ïƒ22)E[\exp (\lambda x)] \leqslant \exp \left(\frac{\lambda^{2} \sigma^{2}}{2}\right) E[exp(Î»x)]â©½exp(2Î»2Ïƒ2â€‹)

Then x is called Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ subgaussian.

æˆ–è€…å†™ä½œmoment generating function ç›¸å…³çš„å½¢å¼

ÏˆX(Î»)=logâ¡MX(Î»)â‰¤12Î»2Ïƒ2Â forÂ allÂ Î»âˆˆR\psi_{X}(\lambda)=\log M_{X}(\lambda) \leq \frac{1}{2} \lambda^{2} \sigma^{2} \quad \text { for all } \lambda \in \mathbb{R}ÏˆXâ€‹(Î»)=logMXâ€‹(Î»)â‰¤21â€‹Î»2Ïƒ2Â forÂ allÂ Î»âˆˆR

è¿™ä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆå« â€œsubgaussianâ€

A random variable XXX is heavy tailed if MX(Î»)=âˆM_{X}(\lambda)=\inftyMXâ€‹(Î»)=âˆ for all Î»>0\lambda>0Î»>0. Otherwise it is light tailed.

The tails of a Ïƒ-subgaussian random variable decay approximately as fast as that of a Gaussian with zero mean and the same variance.

ç‰¹åˆ«çš„xâˆ¼N(0,Ïƒ2)x\sim N(0,\sigma^2)xâˆ¼N(0,Ïƒ2)æ˜¯Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-subgaussian

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆéœ€è¦subgaussianï¼Ÿ å› ä¸ºsubgaussiançš„æ€§è´¨å¯ä»¥å¾—åˆ°å¾ˆå¤šconcentration inequalityï¼Œåœ¨å¸¸è§çš„banditè¯æ˜ä¸­éƒ½å¾ˆä¾èµ–subgaussiançš„æ€§è´¨ã€‚

Thm 3

If XXX is Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ-subgaussian, then âˆ€Îµ>0\forall \varepsilon>0âˆ€Îµ>0,

\begin{align} &P(X>\varepsilon) \leqslant \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}\right) \\ &P(X<-\varepsilon) \leqslant \exp \left(-\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2 \sigma^{2}}\right) \end{align}

Proof:

\begin{align} P(X>\varepsilon)&=P(\exp (\lambda x) \geqslant \exp (\lambda \varepsilon))\\ &\leq \exp (-\lambda \varepsilon) E[\exp (\lambda x)]\text{ (By Markov)}\\ &\leqslant \exp \left(\frac{\lambda^{2} \sigma^{2}}{2}-\lambda \varepsilon\right)\text{ (By Subgaussian)} \end{align}

minimize over Î»\lambdaÎ» , let Î»\lambdaÎ» = Ïµ/Ïƒ2\epsilon/\sigma^2Ïµ/Ïƒ2

Lemma: subgaussian property

Suppose X1,X2X_1,X_2X1â€‹,X2â€‹ are Ïƒ1,Ïƒ2\sigma_1,\sigma_2Ïƒ1â€‹,Ïƒ2â€‹ subgaussian:

  • cX1cX_1cX1â€‹ is âˆ£câˆ£Ïƒ1|c|\sigma_1âˆ£câˆ£Ïƒ1â€‹ subgaussian
  • X1+X2X_1+X_2X1â€‹+X2â€‹ is Ïƒ12+Ïƒ22\sqrt{\sigma_1^2+\sigma_2^2}Ïƒ12â€‹+Ïƒ22â€‹â€‹ subgaussian

åœ¨åæœŸä¹Ÿä¼šä¿æŒä¸€ä¸ªÏµt\epsilon_tÏµtâ€‹ çš„æ¦‚ç‡å°è¯•å…¶ä»–armã€‚

why Ïµt\epsilon_tÏµtâ€‹ not Ïµ\epsilonÏµ ? å¯ä»¥è¯å¾—ï¼Œå½“å–å¸¸æ•°Ïµ\epsilonÏµ å¾—æ—¶å€™regretä¼šè¶‹äºæ— ç©·ã€‚

Regret åˆ†æ

è‹¥å–Ïµâˆ¼1t\epsilon \sim \frac{1}{t}Ïµâˆ¼t1â€‹ then:

Instance Independent âˆ¼O(n)\sim O(\sqrt{n})âˆ¼O(nâ€‹) (åªçŸ¥é“Î¼1,Î¼2â‹¯Î¼k\mu_1,\mu_2\cdots\mu_kÎ¼1â€‹,Î¼2â€‹â‹¯Î¼kâ€‹å–å€¼ç©ºé—´âˆ¼[0,1]\sim [0,1]âˆ¼[0,1])

Instance Dependent âˆ¼O(logâ¡n)\sim O(\log n)âˆ¼O(logn) ï¼ˆçŸ¥é“Î¼1,Î¼2â‹¯Î¼k\mu_1,\mu_2\cdots\mu_kÎ¼1â€‹,Î¼2â€‹â‹¯Î¼kâ€‹ æ˜¯å“ªäº›æ•°ï¼Œä½†ä¸çŸ¥é“å„è‡ªå¯¹åº”å“ªä¸ªarmï¼‰

Upper Confidence Bound Algorithm

è‘—åçš„ä¸Šç½®ä¿¡åº¦è¾¹ç•Œï¼ˆUCBï¼‰ç®—æ³•ï¼Œå®ƒå…‹æœäº†ETCçš„ç­–ç•¥çš„æ‰€æœ‰é™åˆ¶ï¼ŒåŒ…æ‹¬éœ€è¦çŸ¥é“æ°´å¹³çº¿å’Œæ¬¡ä¼˜å·®è·ã€‚è¯¥ç®—æ³•æœ‰è®¸å¤šä¸åŒçš„å½¢å¼ï¼Œå–å†³äºå¯¹å™ªå£°åˆ†å¸ƒçš„å‡è®¾ã€‚

ç®—æ³•æ€æƒ³

UCBç®—æ³•ç»™äººä»¬çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå¯ç¤ºæ˜¯â€œæ°¸è¿œå¯¹æœªçŸ¥ä¿æŒä¹è§‚æ€åº¦â€

Recall that if X1,X2,â€¦,XnX_{1}, X_{2}, \dots, X_{n}X1â€‹,X2â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹ are independent and 1-subgaussian (which means that E[Xi]=0\mathbb{E}[X_{i}]=0E[Xiâ€‹]=0 ) and Î¼^=âˆ‘t=1nXt/n\hat{\mu}=\sum_{t=1}^{n} X_{t} / nÎ¼^â€‹=âˆ‘t=1nâ€‹Xtâ€‹/n, then

P(Î¼^â‰¥Îµ)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’nÎµ2/2)\mathbb{P}(\hat{\mu} \geq \varepsilon) \leq \exp (-n \varepsilon^{2} / 2) P(Î¼^â€‹â‰¥Îµ)â‰¤exp(âˆ’nÎµ2/2)

Equating the right-hand side with Î´\deltaÎ´ and solving for Îµ\varepsilonÎµ leads to

\begin{equation} A_{t}= \begin{cases}\operatorname{argmax}_{i}(\hat{\mu}_{i}(t-1)+\sqrt{\frac{2 \log \frac{1}{\delta}}{T_{i}(t-1)}}), & \text { if } t>K \\ t, & \text { otherwise }\end{cases} \end{equation}

Besides the slightly vague "optimism guarantees optimality or learning" intuition we gave before, it is worth exploring other intuitions for this choice of index. At a very basic level, we should explore arms more often if they are:

  • (a) promising (in that Î¼^i(tâˆ’1)\hat{\mu}_{i}(t-1)Î¼^â€‹iâ€‹(tâˆ’1) is large)
  • (b) not well explored ( Ti(tâˆ’1)T_{i}(t-1)Tiâ€‹(tâˆ’1) is small).

Î¼1âˆ’Î¼Atâ‰¤22logâ¡(1Ïƒ)1TAt(tâˆ’1)\mu_{1}-\mu_{A_{t}} \leq 2 \sqrt{2 \log (\frac{1}{\sigma})} \sqrt{\frac{1}{T_{A_{t}}(t-1)}}Î¼1â€‹âˆ’Î¼Atâ€‹â€‹â‰¤22log(Ïƒ1â€‹)â€‹TAtâ€‹â€‹(tâˆ’1)1â€‹â€‹

We know Ti(tâˆ’1)â‰¤tâˆ’1T_{i}(t-1) \leq t-1Tiâ€‹(tâˆ’1)â‰¤tâˆ’1

âˆ‘t=1nE[1TAt(tâˆ’1)]â©½âˆ‘t=1nâˆ‘i=1k1tâˆ¼kn\sum_{t=1}^{n} E[\sqrt{\frac{1}{T_{A_{t}}(t-1)}}] \leqslant \sum_{t=1}^{n} \sum_{i=1}^{k} \sqrt{\frac{1}{t}} \sim k \sqrt{n} t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹E[TAtâ€‹â€‹(tâˆ’1)1â€‹â€‹]â©½t=1âˆ‘nâ€‹i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹t1â€‹â€‹âˆ¼knâ€‹

è¿™ä¸€æ­¥æ”¾ç¼©è¿‡å¤§ï¼Œæ¯ä¸ªarm iæ‹‰çš„æ¬¡æ•°å°äºtæ¬¡ï¼Œç›´æ¥éƒ½æ”¾ç¼©åˆ°tæ¬¡

Regret | Good Event â‰¤\leqâ‰¤âˆ‘t=1n22logâ¡(1Î´)E[1TAt(tâˆ’1)]âˆ¼22logâ¡1Ïƒkn\sum_{t=1}^{n} 2 \sqrt{2 \log (\frac{1}{\delta})} E[\sqrt{\frac{1}{T_{A_{t}}(t-1)}}]\sim2 \sqrt{2 \log \frac{1}{\sigma }} k \sqrt{n}âˆ‘t=1nâ€‹22log(Î´1â€‹)â€‹E[TAtâ€‹â€‹(tâˆ’1)1â€‹â€‹]âˆ¼22logÏƒ1â€‹â€‹knâ€‹

åäº‹ä»¶ä¸‹è¦å°è¯•è¯æ˜ï¼Œåäº‹ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡ä¸ä¼šè¿‡å¤§

ä¸ºäº†æ–¹ä¾¿è®¨è®ºï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬denoteä¸€ä¸‹æ¯ä¸ªarmçš„ç”Ÿæˆåºåˆ—(æ¯ä¸ªarméƒ½è€ƒè™‘åˆ°næœŸ)

Let Eti=âˆ£âˆ‘s=1tXsitâˆ’Î¼iâˆ£â‰¤2logâ¡(1Ïƒ)tE_{t_{i}}=|\frac{\sum_{s=1}^{t} X _{si}}{t}-\mu_{i}| \leq \sqrt{\frac{2 \log (\frac{1}{\sigma})}{t}}Etiâ€‹â€‹=âˆ£tâˆ‘s=1tâ€‹Xsiâ€‹â€‹âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹âˆ£â‰¤t2log(Ïƒ1â€‹)â€‹â€‹

entry.title: Paper Reading
entry.content:
Robust Monopoly Regulation(AER RR)

Yingni Guo ï¼ŒEran Shmaya

1 Introduction & Environment

There is a monopolistic firm and a mass one of consumers.

Inverse-demand function:

â€‹ V:[0,1]â†’[0,vË‰]V:[0,1] \rightarrow[0, \bar{v}]V:[0,1]â†’[0,vË‰]

â€‹ A quantity-price pair (q,p)âˆˆ[0,1]Ã—[0,vË‰](q, p) \in [0,1] \times[0, \bar{v}](q,p)âˆˆ[0,1]Ã—[0,vË‰] is feasible if and only if it is below the inverse-demand function, i.e., pâ©½V(q)p \leqslant V(q)pâ©½V(q). â€‹ The total value to consumers of quantity qqq is the area under the inverse-demand function given by âˆ«0qV(z)dz\int_{0}^{q} V(z) \mathrm{d} zâˆ«0qâ€‹V(z)dz

Optimal total surplus:

OPTâ¡(V,C)=maxâ¡qâˆˆ[0,1](âˆ«0qV(z)dzâˆ’C(q))\operatorname{OPT}(V, C)=\max _{q \in[0,1]}\left(\int_{0}^{q} V(z) \mathrm{d} z-C(q)\right) OPT(V,C)=qâˆˆ[0,1]maxâ€‹(âˆ«0qâ€‹V(z)dzâˆ’C(q))

Distortion of total surplus(with quantity q):

DSTRâ¡(V,C,q)=OPTâ¡(V,C)âˆ’(âˆ«0qV(z)dzâˆ’C(q))\operatorname{DSTR}(V, C, q)=\operatorname{OPT}(V, C)-\left(\int_{0}^{q} V(z) \mathrm{d} z-C(q)\right) DSTR(V,C,q)=OPT(V,C)âˆ’(âˆ«0qâ€‹V(z)dzâˆ’C(q))

Regulatory policies:

â€‹ Revenue of the firm: Ï(q,p)\rho(q, p)Ï(q,p)

  1. subsidy : Ï(q,p)=qp+s\rho(q, p) = qp + sÏ(q,p)=qp+sâ€‹
  2. tax: Ï(q,p)=qpâˆ’t\rho(q, p) = qp - tÏ(q,p)=qpâˆ’t
  3. price cap: Ï(q,p)=minâ¡(qp,qk)\rho(q, p) =\min (q p, q k)Ï(q,p)=min(qp,qk)

**Consumer surplus and Firm payoff : **

CS(V,Ï,q,p)=âˆ«0qV(z)dzâˆ’Ï(q,p)FP(V,C,Ï,q,p)=Ï(q,p)âˆ’C(q)\mathrm{CS}(V, \rho, q, p)=\int_{0}^{q} V(z) \mathrm{d} z-\rho(q, p)\\ \mathrm{FP}(V, C, \rho, q, p)=\rho(q, p)-C(q) CS(V,Ï,q,p)=âˆ«0qâ€‹V(z)dzâˆ’Ï(q,p)FP(V,C,Ï,q,p)=Ï(q,p)âˆ’C(q)

2 Problem

â€‹ The regulator's payoff is a wseighted sum: CS+Î±FP,Î±âˆˆ(0,1)CS + \alpha FP, \alpha \in (0,1)CS+Î±FP,Î±âˆˆ(0,1)â€‹

Complete Information Payoff :

CIPâ¡(V,C)=maxâ¡Ï,q,p(CSâ¡(V,Ï,q,p)+Î±FP(V,C,Ï,q,p))\operatorname{CIP}(V, C)=\max _{\rho, q, p}(\operatorname{CS}(V, \rho, q, p)+\alpha \mathrm{FP}(V, C, \rho, q, p)) CIP(V,C)=Ï,q,pmaxâ€‹(CS(V,Ï,q,p)+Î±FP(V,C,Ï,q,p))

Proposition 1:

CIP(V,C)=OPT(V,C)\mathrm{CIP}(V, C)=\mathrm{OPT}(V, C) CIP(V,C)=OPT(V,C)

Ï(q,p)={C(qâˆ—)Â ifÂ (q,p)=(qâˆ—,V(qâˆ—))0Â otherwiseÂ \rho(q, p)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} C\left(q^{*}\right) & \text { if }(q, p)=\left(q^{*}, V\left(q^{*}\right)\right) \\ 0 & \text { otherwise } \end{array}\right. Ï(q,p)={C(qâˆ—)0â€‹Â ifÂ (q,p)=(qâˆ—,V(qâˆ—))Â otherwiseÂ â€‹

Regret:

RGRTâ¡(V,C,Ï,q,p)=CIPâ¡(V,C)âˆ’(CSâ¡(V,Ï,q,p)+Î±FP(V,C,Ï,q,p))\operatorname{RGRT}(V, C, \rho, q, p)=\operatorname{CIP}(V, C)-(\operatorname{CS}(V, \rho, q, p)+\alpha \mathrm{FP}(V, C, \rho, q, p)) RGRT(V,C,Ï,q,p)=CIP(V,C)âˆ’(CS(V,Ï,q,p)+Î±FP(V,C,Ï,q,p))

RGRT=CIPâˆ’(CS+Î±FP)=OPTâˆ’(CS+Î±FP)=OPTâˆ’(CS+FP)+(1âˆ’Î±)FP=DSTR+(1âˆ’Î±)FP\begin{aligned} \mathrm{RGRT} &=\mathrm{CIP}-(\mathrm{CS}+\alpha \mathrm{FP})=\mathrm{OPT}-(\mathrm{CS}+\alpha \mathrm{FP}) \\ &=\mathrm{OPT}-(\mathrm{CS}+\mathrm{FP})+(1-\alpha) \mathrm{FP} \\ &=\mathrm{DSTR}+(1-\alpha) \mathrm{FP} \end{aligned} RGRTâ€‹=CIPâˆ’(CS+Î±FP)=OPTâˆ’(CS+Î±FP)=OPTâˆ’(CS+FP)+(1âˆ’Î±)FP=DSTR+(1âˆ’Î±)FPâ€‹

minimizeâ¡Ïmaxâ¡V,C,q,pRGRTâ¡(V,C,Ï,q,p)\underset{\rho}{\operatorname{minimize}} \max _{V, C, q, p} \operatorname{RGRT}(V, C, \rho, q, p) Ïminimizeâ€‹V,C,q,pmaxâ€‹RGRT(V,C,Ï,q,p)

3 Main Result

Price Cap k

kÎ±=vË‰2âˆ’Î±k_{\alpha}=\frac{\bar{v}}{2-\alpha}kÎ±â€‹=2âˆ’Î±vË‰â€‹

**Proposition 2ï¼š**The worst-case regret under any policy is at least (1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±=1âˆ’Î±2âˆ’Î±vË‰(1-\alpha) k_{\alpha}=\frac{1-\alpha}{2-\alpha} \bar{v}(1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±â€‹=2âˆ’Î±1âˆ’Î±â€‹vË‰.

Theorem 1:

Lower bound on worst-case regret:

rÎ±=maxâ¡qâˆˆ[0,1],pâˆˆ[0,kÎ±]minâ¡(q(1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±âˆ’qplogâ¡q,q(kÎ±âˆ’p))r_{\alpha}=\max _{q \in[0,1], p \in\left[0, k_{\alpha}\right]} \min \left(q(1-\alpha) k_{\alpha}-q p \log q, q\left(k_{\alpha}-p\right)\right) rÎ±â€‹=qâˆˆ[0,1],pâˆˆ[0,kÎ±â€‹]maxâ€‹min(q(1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±â€‹âˆ’qplogq,q(kÎ±â€‹âˆ’p))

rÎ±=vË‰{1âˆ’Î±2âˆ’Î±Î±â©½12(2+Î±âˆ’Î±(Î±+4))e1âˆ’Î±+Î±(Î±+4)22(2âˆ’Î±)Î±>12.,qÎ±={1,Â ifÂ Î±â©½1/2e1âˆ’Î±+Î±(Î±+4)2,Â ifÂ Î±>1/2r_{\alpha}=\bar{v}\left\{\begin{array}{ll} \frac{1-\alpha}{2-\alpha} & \alpha \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{(2+\alpha-\sqrt{\alpha(\alpha+4)}) e^{1-\frac{\alpha+\sqrt{\alpha(\alpha+4)}}{2}}}{2(2-\alpha)} & \alpha>\frac{1}{2} . \end{array}, \quad q_{\alpha}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll} 1, & \text { if } \alpha \leqslant 1 / 2 \\ e^{1-\frac{\alpha+\sqrt{\alpha(\alpha+4)}}{2}}, & \text { if } \alpha>1 / 2 \end{array}\right.\right. rÎ±â€‹=vË‰â©âªâ¨âªâ§â€‹2âˆ’Î±1âˆ’Î±â€‹2(2âˆ’Î±)(2+Î±âˆ’Î±(Î±+4)â€‹)e1âˆ’2Î±+Î±(Î±+4)â€‹â€‹â€‹â€‹Î±â©½21â€‹Î±>21â€‹.â€‹,qÎ±â€‹={1,e1âˆ’2Î±+Î±(Î±+4)â€‹â€‹,â€‹Â ifÂ Î±â©½1/2Â ifÂ Î±>1/2â€‹

Theorem 2 (Optimal policy). Let

sÎ±=supâ¡{q(kÎ±âˆ’p):qâˆˆ[0,1],pâˆˆ[0,kÎ±],q(1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±âˆ’qplogâ¡q>rÎ±}s_{\alpha}=\sup \left\{q\left(k_{\alpha}-p\right): q \in[0,1], p \in\left[0, k_{\alpha}\right], q(1-\alpha) k_{\alpha}-q p \log q>r_{\alpha}\right\} sÎ±â€‹=sup{q(kÎ±â€‹âˆ’p):qâˆˆ[0,1],pâˆˆ[0,kÎ±â€‹],q(1âˆ’Î±)kÎ±â€‹âˆ’qplogq>rÎ±â€‹}

The policy

Ï(q,p)=minâ¡(qkÎ±,qp+s)\rho(q, p)=\min \left(q k_{\alpha}, q p+s\right) Ï(q,p)=min(qkÎ±â€‹,qp+s)

with sÎ±â©½sâ©½rÎ±s_{\alpha} \leqslant s \leqslant r_{\alpha}sÎ±â€‹â©½sâ©½rÎ±â€‹ achieves the worst-case regret rÎ±r_{\alpha}rÎ±â€‹.

sÎ±={vË‰Î±2âˆ’Î±Â ifÂ Î±â©½12rÎ±Â ifÂ Î±>12s_{\alpha}=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\bar{v} \frac{\alpha}{2-\alpha} & \text { if } \alpha \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \\ r_{\alpha} & \text { if } \alpha>\frac{1}{2}\end{array}\right.sÎ±â€‹={vË‰2âˆ’Î±Î±â€‹rÎ±â€‹â€‹Â ifÂ Î±â©½21â€‹Â ifÂ Î±>21â€‹â€‹

Theorem 3: Let Ï\rhoÏ be an optimal policy. Then

  1. (Price cap): Ï(q,p)â©½qkÎ±\rho(q, p) \leqslant q k_{\alpha}Ï(q,p)â©½qkÎ±â€‹ for every qâ©½qÎ±q \leqslant q_{\alpha}qâ©½qÎ±â€‹.

  2. (Subsidy): There exists some (q,p)(q, p)(q,p) such that Ï(q,p)â©¾qp+sÎ±\rho(q, p) \geqslant q p+s_{\alpha}Ï(q,p)â©¾qp+sÎ±â€‹.

  3. (Subsidy cap): Ï(q,p)â©½qp+rÎ±\rho(q, p) \leqslant q p+r_{\alpha}Ï(q,p)â©½qp+rÎ±â€‹â€‹ for every (q,p)(q, p)(q,p)

Trade off between 3 parts:

  1. Giving more surplus to consumer(Surplus redistribution)

    ä½“ç°åœ¨price capè®¾ç½®ä¸Šï¼Œprice cap é™åˆ¶monopoly firm cannot get more than kÎ±k_\alphakÎ±â€‹â€‹ from consumer.

  2. Underproduction

    For low quantity, subsidy is piece-rate increasing, incentivize the firm to producemore.

  3. Overproduction

    The subsidize is capped , so the potential overproduction is under control.

entry.title: Paper Reading
entry.content:
Parallel Lottery

Parallel Lotteries: Insights from Alaskan Hunting Permit Allocation

Nick Arnosti,Â Tim Randolph

Introduction:

Analyze the parallel lottery that is used to allocate heterogeneous resources to unit-demand agents.

Notation and Preliminary

  1. nnn types of items with quantities Î¼=(Î¼1,Î¼2â€¦,Î¼n)âˆˆR+n.\mu=\left(\mu_{1}, \mu_{2}\right.\left.\ldots, \mu_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n} .Î¼=(Î¼1â€‹,Î¼2â€‹â€¦,Î¼nâ€‹)âˆˆR+nâ€‹.
  2. Mass MMM of agents.
  3. Each agent is identified by a type v=(v1,v2,â€¦vn)âˆˆRnv=\left(v_{1}, v_{2}, \ldots v_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{R}^{n}v=(v1â€‹,v2â€‹,â€¦vnâ€‹)âˆˆRn

Single agent decision problem:

Given strategy sss and win probabilities ppp.

  • sis_isiâ€‹: number of tickets an agent puts on item i.
  • pip_ipiâ€‹: Probability of draw a ticket of item i.

Ï‡(s,p)={Ï‡i(s,p)}i=1n\chi(s, p)=\left\{\chi_{i}(s, p)\right\}_{i=1}^{n}Ï‡(s,p)={Ï‡iâ€‹(s,p)}i=1nâ€‹Â  summaries the probability of winning each object

\begin{equation}\chi_{i}(s, p):=\left(1-\left(1-p_{i}\right)^{s_{i}}\right) \prod_{j>i}\left(1-p_{j}\right)^{s_{j}}\end{equation}

w(v,s,p):=vâ‹…Ï‡(s,p)w(v, s, p):=v \cdot \chi(s, p) w(v,s,p):=vâ‹…Ï‡(s,p)

Optimal Strategyï¼š Greedy Algorithm

K-Equilibrium

Consider k ticket strategy profile Î¦(v)=sk\Phi(v) = s^kÎ¦(v)=sk (âˆ‘(si)=k\sum(s_i) = kâˆ‘(siâ€‹)=k)

For any k parallel lottery there exists ****k-ticket ****equilibrium pair (Î¦,p)(\Phi, p)(Î¦,p)

Equilibrium Efficiency Analysis

Allocation x is Î±-Pareto efficient if for every feasible allocation y (Î±â‰¥1\alpha\geq 1Î±â‰¥1).

\begin{equation}\eta\left(\left\{v: \frac{y(v) \cdot v}{x(v) \cdot v} \leq \alpha .\right\}\right)>0\end{equation}

Theorem 1: Any equilibrium of the k-ticket parallel lottery is 1(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1k+1)k)\frac{1}{\left(1-\left(1-\frac{1}{k+1}\right)^{k}\right)}(1âˆ’(1âˆ’k+11â€‹)k)1â€‹-Pareto efficient.

(This converges to eeâˆ’1\frac{e}{e-1}eâˆ’1eâ€‹)

Theorem 1 gives the bound of the inefficiency f k-parallel but didn't provide any insight into such inefficiency.

2 types of Inefficiency

Trade Reallocation(Trade Efficiency)

A trade reallocation of xxx is a feasible allocation yyy such that âˆ«x(v)dÎ·=âˆ«y(v)dÎ·\int x(v) d \eta=\int y(v) d \etaâˆ«x(v)dÎ·=âˆ«y(v)dÎ·.

Allocation xxx is âˆ—âˆ—Î±**\alphaâˆ—âˆ—Î±-trade efficient** if for any yyy that is a trade reallocation of xxx, (2) holds.

An allocation is trade efficient if it is 1-trade efficient

Any k-ticket equilibrium is 1(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1/k)k)\frac{1}{\left(1-(1-1 / k)^{k}\right)}(1âˆ’(1âˆ’1/k)k)1â€‹-trade efficient.

Waste Reallocation(Wasteful Efficiency)

A waste reallocation of xxx is a feasible allocation yyy such that for every vvv and every iii that is fully allocated under x,yi(v)â‰¤xi(v)x, y_{i}(v) \leq x_{i}(v)x,yiâ€‹(v)â‰¤xiâ€‹(v).

Allocation xxx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-wasteful if for any yyy that is a waste reallocation of xxx, and any vvv, (vâ‹…y(v))/(vâ‹…x(v))â‰¤1+Ïµ.(v \cdot y(v)) /(v \cdot x(v)) \leq 1+\epsilon .(vâ‹…y(v))/(vâ‹…x(v))â‰¤1+Ïµ.

An allocation is non-wasteful if it is 0-wasteful.

Any k-ticket equilibrium is 1k\frac{1}{k}k1â€‹-waste efficient.

Effect of changing K

Only 2 items and we use v=v2v1v = \frac{v_2}{v_1}v=v1â€‹v2â€‹â€‹ to denote the agent's type.

Proposition 1

With most people strongly prefer item 1(vâ‰ª1v\ll1vâ‰ª1) and some agents nearly indifferent(vâ‰ˆ1v\approx1vâ‰ˆ1).

If Î¼1+Î¼2>1\mu_1+\mu_2 >1Î¼1â€‹+Î¼2â€‹>1 then in every non-wasteful and envy-free allocation. Every agent gets an item and item 1 is allocated randomly to those who prefer item 1.(when kâ†’âˆk\rightarrow \inftykâ†’âˆ the equilibrium behave like this)

Proposition 2

Agents with Strong Preferences Prefer Smaller k.

Example:

  • Tradeoff Regime: Increase k befits agent to compete for under demanded items and hurt agents with strong preference.
  • Waste Trap Regime: If most agents strongly prefer item 1 then small k will not reduce competition but just cost more waste.

entry.title: Basic Auction Theory
entry.content:
Basic Auction theory

1 Introduction

â€‹ Auction theory can be approached from different angles â€“ from the perspective of game theory (auctions are bayesian games of incomplete information), contract or mechanism design theory (auctions are allocation mechanisms), market microstructure (auctions are models of price formation), as well as in the context of different applications (procurement, patent licensing, public finance, etc.).

â€‹ Generally speaking, the higher the bidder offer the higher chance he will get the good but also he will get less profit, vice versa.

The basic auction environment consists of:

  • Bidders $$i=1, \ldots, n$$
  • One object to be sold
  • Bidder $$i$$ observes a "signal" $$S_{i} \sim F(\cdot)$$, with typical realization $$s_{i} \in$$ $$[\underline{s}, \bar{s}]$$, and assume $$F$$ is continuous.
  • Bidders' signals $$S_{1}, \ldots, S_{n}$$ are independent.
  • Bidder iii 's value $$v_{i}\left(s_{i}\right)=s_{i}$$

2 Different Auction Forms

1) English auction(oral ascending):

All bidders start in the auction with a price of zero. The price rises continuously, and bidders may drop out at any point in time. Once they drop out, they cannot reenter. The auction ends when only one bidder is left, and this bidder pays the price at which the second-to-last bidder dropped out.

2) Dutch Auction(descending price)

A Dutch auction is one of several similar types of auctions for buying or selling goods.Most commonly, it means an auction in which the auctioneer begins with a high asking price in the case of selling, and lowers it until some participant accepts the price, or it reaches a predetermined reserve price. This type of price auction is most commonly used for goods that are required to be sold quickly such as flowers, fresh produce or tobacco.

3) First-price sealed-bid auction

Also known as blind bid all bidders simultaneously submit sealed bids so that no bidder knows the bid of any other participant. The highest bidder pays the price that was submitted.

4) Second-price sealed-bid auction(vickery auction)

In a Vickrey, or second price, auction, bidders are asked to submit sealed bids $$b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}$$. The bidder who submits the highest bid is awarded the object, and pays the amount of the second highest bid.

3 First-price sealed-bid auction(FPSD)

In a FPSD auction the bidders sealed bids $$b_1,b_2\dots b_n$$ the bidders who submits the highest bid is awarded the object and pays his bid.

Under these rules the bidder will not bid higher than their values, by doing so they may get negative profit. By bidding lower than their true value they may make profit some time.

A The first order condition approach

We will look for an equilibrium where each bidder uses a bid strategy that is a strictly increasing, continuous, and differentiable function of his value. To do this we assume that different bidders use the same bid function $$b_j = b(s_j)$$ for different j.

Bidder i's expected profit as a function of his bid $$b_i$$ and signal $$s_i$$

U(bi,si)=(siâˆ’bi)â‹…Prâ¡[bj=b(Sj)â‰¤bi,âˆ€jâ‰ i]U\left(b_{i}, s_{i}\right)=\left(s_{i}-b_{i}\right) \cdot \operatorname{Pr}\left[b_{j}=b\left(S_{j}\right) \leq b_{i}, \forall j \neq i\right] U(biâ€‹,siâ€‹)=(siâ€‹âˆ’biâ€‹)â‹…Pr[bjâ€‹=b(Sjâ€‹)â‰¤biâ€‹,âˆ€jî€ =i]

Thus, bidder i chooses b to solve:

maxâ¡bi(siâˆ’bi)Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(bi))\max _{b_{i}}\left(s_{i}-b_{i}\right) F^{n-1}\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right) biâ€‹maxâ€‹(siâ€‹âˆ’biâ€‹)Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))

The first order condition is:

(siâˆ’bi)(nâˆ’1)Fnâˆ’2(bâˆ’1(bi))f(bâˆ’1(bi))1bâ€²(bâˆ’1(bi))âˆ’Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(bi))=0\left(s_{i}-b_{i}\right)(n-1) F^{n-2}\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right) f\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right) \frac{1}{b^{\prime}\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right)}-F^{n-1}\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right)=0 (siâ€‹âˆ’biâ€‹)(nâˆ’1)Fnâˆ’2(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))f(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))bâ€²(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))1â€‹âˆ’Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))=0

At a symmetric equilibrium, $$b_{i}=b\left(s_{i}\right)$$, so the first order condition reduces to a differential equation (here I'll drop the iii subscript):

bâ€²(s)=(sâˆ’b(s))(nâˆ’1)f(s)F(s)b^{\prime}(s)=(s-b(s))(n-1) \frac{f(s)}{F(s)} bâ€²(s)=(sâˆ’b(s))(nâˆ’1)F(s)f(s)â€‹

This can be solved, using the boundary condition that $$b(\underline{s})=\underline{s}$$, to obtain:

b(s)=sâˆ’âˆ«sâ€¾siFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~Fnâˆ’1(s)b(s)=s-\frac{\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}}{F^{n-1}(s)} b(s)=sâˆ’Fnâˆ’1(s)âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~â€‹

It is easy to check that b(s) is increasing and differentiable. So any symmetric equilibrium with these properties must involve bidders using the strategy b(s).

The envelope theorem approach

For bidder i, his equilibrium payoff is:

U\left(s_{i}\right)=\left(s_{i}-b\left(s_{i}\right)\right) F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right)\label{usi_1}

Because i is playing the best-response in equilibrium, so:

U(si)=maxâ¡bi(siâˆ’bi)Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(bi))U\left(s_{i}\right)=\max _{b_{i}}\left(s_{i}-b_{i}\right) F^{n-1}\left(b^{-1}\left(b_{i}\right)\right) U(siâ€‹)=biâ€‹maxâ€‹(siâ€‹âˆ’biâ€‹)Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(biâ€‹))

Applying the Envelope Theorem we can get:

ddsU(s)âˆ£s=si=Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(b(si))=Fnâˆ’1(si)\left.\frac{d}{d s} U(s)\right|_{s=s_{i}}=F^{n-1}\left(b^{-1}\left(b\left(s_{i}\right)\right)=F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right)\right. dsdâ€‹U(s)âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹s=siâ€‹â€‹=Fnâˆ’1(bâˆ’1(b(siâ€‹))=Fnâˆ’1(siâ€‹)

and also:

U\left(s_{i}\right)=U(\underline{s})+\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s} \label{usi_2}

As b(s) is increasing a bidder with signal sâ€¾\underline{s}sâ€‹ will never win the auction so we have U(sâ€¾)=0U(\underline{s})=0U(sâ€‹)=0, combine \eqref{usi_1} and \eqref{usi_2} we can easily get:

b(s)=sâˆ’âˆ«sâ€¾siFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~Fnâˆ’1(s)b(s)=s-\frac{\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}}{F^{n-1}(s)} b(s)=sâˆ’Fnâˆ’1(s)âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~â€‹

4 Vickery auction( Second price auction)

In a Vickrey, or second price auction, bidders are asked to submit sealed bids $$b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}$$. The bidder who submits the highest bid is awarded the object, and pays the amount of the second highest bid.

Proposition 1 In a second price auction, it is a weakly dominant strategy to bid one's value $$b_i(s_i) = s_i$$

(Easy to be proved, omitted here)

Since each bidder will bid their value, the seller's revenue (the amount paid in equilibrium) will be equal to the second highest value. Let $$S^{i: n}$$ denote the iii th highest of nnn draws from distribution $$F$$ (so $$S^{i: n}$$ is a random variable with typical realization $$\left.s^{i: n}\right)$$. Then the seller's expected revenue is $$\mathbb{E}\left[S^{2: n}\right] .$$

5 Revenue equivalence

What is the revenue from the first price auction? It is the expected winning bid, or the expected bid of the bidder with the highest signal, $$E[b(S^{1:n})]$$ To sharpen this, define $$G(s)=F^{n-1}(s) .$$Then $$G$$ is the probability that if you take $$n-1$$ draws from $$F$$, all will be below $$s$$ (i.e. it is the cdf of $$S^{1: n-1}$$ ). Then,

b(s)=sâˆ’âˆ«sâ€¾sFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~Fnâˆ’1(s)=1Fnâˆ’1(s)âˆ«sâ€¾ss~dFnâˆ’1(s~)=E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1â‰¤s]b(s)=s-\frac{\int_{\underline{s}}^{s} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}}{F^{n-1}(s)}=\frac{1}{F^{n-1}(s)} \int_{\underline{s}}^{s} \tilde{s} d F^{n-1}(\tilde{s})=\mathbb{E}\left[S^{1: n-1} \mid S^{1: n-1} \leq s\right] b(s)=sâˆ’Fnâˆ’1(s)âˆ«sâ€‹sâ€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~â€‹=Fnâˆ’1(s)1â€‹âˆ«sâ€‹sâ€‹s~dFnâˆ’1(s~)=E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1â‰¤s]

That is, if a bidder has signal s, he sets his bid equal to the expectation of the highest of the other n-1â€‹ values, conditional on all those values being less than his own. Using this fact, the expected revenue is:

E[b(S1:n)]=E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1â‰¤S1:n]=E[S2:n]\mathbb{E}\left[b\left(S^{1: n}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[S^{1: n-1} \mid S^{1: n-1} \leq S^{1: n}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[S^{2: n}\right] E[b(S1:n)]=E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1â‰¤S1:n]=E[S2:n]

equal to the expectation of the second highest value. We have shown:

Proposition 2 The first and second price auction yield the same revenue in expectation.

The result above is a special case of the celebrated â€œrevenue equivalence theoremâ€ .

Revenue Equivalence Theorem :Suppose n bidders have values $$s_{1}, \ldots, s_{n}$$ identically and independently distributed with cdf $$F(\cdot) .$$ Then all auction mechanisms that (i) always award the object to the bidder with highest value in equilibrium, and (ii) give a bidder with valuation $$\underline{s}$$ zero profits, generates the same revenue in expectation.

proof:

We consider the general class of auctions where bidders submit bids $$b_1,\dots,b_n$$. An auction rule specifies for all i,

xi:B1Ã—â€¦Ã—Bnâ†’[0,1]ti:B1Ã—â€¦Ã—Bnâ†’R\begin{aligned} x_{i} &: B_{1} \times \ldots \times B_{n} \rightarrow[0,1] \\ t_{i} &: B_{1} \times \ldots \times B_{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R} \end{aligned} xiâ€‹tiâ€‹â€‹:B1â€‹Ã—â€¦Ã—Bnâ€‹â†’[0,1]:B1â€‹Ã—â€¦Ã—Bnâ€‹â†’Râ€‹

where $$x_{i}(\cdot)$$ gives the probability iii will get the object and $$t_{i}(\cdot)$$ gives iii 's required payment as a function of the bids $$\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$$ . (For example in a first price auction, $$x_{1}\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$$ equals 1 if $$b_{1}$$ is the highest bid, and otherwise zero. Meanwhile $$t_{1}\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}\right)$$ equals zero unless $$b_{1}$$ is highest, in which case $$t_{1}=b_{1}$$)

Given the auction rule, bidder iii 's expected payoff as a function of his signal and bid is:

Ui(si,bi)=siEbâˆ’i[xi(bi,bâˆ’i)]âˆ’Ebâˆ’i[ti(bi,bâˆ’i)]U_{i}\left(s_{i}, b_{i}\right)=s_{i} \mathbb{E}_{b_{-i}}\left[x_{i}\left(b_{i}, b_{-i}\right)\right]-\mathbb{E}_{b_{-i}}\left[t_{i}\left(b_{i}, b_{-i}\right)\right] Uiâ€‹(siâ€‹,biâ€‹)=siâ€‹Ebâˆ’iâ€‹â€‹[xiâ€‹(biâ€‹,bâˆ’iâ€‹)]âˆ’Ebâˆ’iâ€‹â€‹[tiâ€‹(biâ€‹,bâˆ’iâ€‹)]

Let $$b_{i}(\cdot), b_{-i}(\cdot)$$ denote an equilibrium of the auction game. Bidder iii 's equilibrium payoff is:

Ui(si)=Ui(si,b(si))=siFnâˆ’1(si)âˆ’Esâˆ’i[ti(bi(si),bâˆ’i(sâˆ’i)]U_{i}\left(s_{i}\right)=U_{i}\left(s_{i}, b\left(s_{i}\right)\right)=s_{i} F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{s_{-i}}\left[t_{i}\left(b_{i}\left(s_{i}\right), b_{-i}\left(s_{-i}\right)\right]\right. Uiâ€‹(siâ€‹)=Uiâ€‹(siâ€‹,b(siâ€‹))=siâ€‹Fnâˆ’1(siâ€‹)âˆ’Esâˆ’iâ€‹â€‹[tiâ€‹(biâ€‹(siâ€‹),bâˆ’iâ€‹(sâˆ’iâ€‹)]

where we use (i) to write $$\mathbb{E}{s{-i}}\left[x_{i}\left(b\left(s_{i}\right), b\left(s_{-i}\right)\right)\right]=F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right)$$. Using the fact that $$b\left(s_{i}\right)$$ must maximize iii 's payoff given $$s_{i}$$ and opponent strategies $$b_{-i}(\cdot)$$, the envelope theorem implies that:

ddsUi(s)âˆ£s=si=Ebâˆ’i[xi(bi(si),bâˆ’i(sâˆ’i))]=Fnâˆ’1(si)\left.\frac{d}{d s} U_{i}(s)\right|_{s=s_{i}}=\mathbb{E}_{b_{-i}}\left[x_{i}\left(b_{i}\left(s_{i}\right), b_{-i}\left(s_{-i}\right)\right)\right]=F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right) dsdâ€‹Uiâ€‹(s)âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£âˆ£â€‹s=siâ€‹â€‹=Ebâˆ’iâ€‹â€‹[xiâ€‹(biâ€‹(siâ€‹),bâˆ’iâ€‹(sâˆ’iâ€‹))]=Fnâˆ’1(siâ€‹)

and also

Ui(si)=Ui(sâ€¾)+âˆ«sâ€¾siFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~=âˆ«sâ€¾siFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~,U_{i}\left(s_{i}\right)=U_{i}(\underline{s})+\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}=\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}, Uiâ€‹(siâ€‹)=Uiâ€‹(sâ€‹)+âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~=âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~,

where we use (ii)(i i)(ii) to write $$U_{i}(\underline{s})=0$$ Combining our expressions for $$U_{i}\left(s_{i}\right)$$, we get bidder iii 's expected payment given his signal:

Esâˆ’i[ti(bi,bâˆ’i)]=siFnâˆ’1(si)âˆ’âˆ«sâ€¾siFnâˆ’1(s~)ds~=âˆ«sâ€¾sis~dFnâˆ’1(s~)\mathbb{E}_{s_{-i}}\left[t_{i}\left(b_{i}, b_{-i}\right)\right]=s_{i} F^{n-1}\left(s_{i}\right)-\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) d \tilde{s}=\int_{\underline{s}}^{s_{i}} \tilde{s} d F^{n-1}(\tilde{s}) Esâˆ’iâ€‹â€‹[tiâ€‹(biâ€‹,bâˆ’iâ€‹)]=siâ€‹Fnâˆ’1(siâ€‹)âˆ’âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹Fnâˆ’1(s~)ds~=âˆ«sâ€‹siâ€‹â€‹s~dFnâˆ’1(s~)

where the last equality is from integration by parts. Since $$x_{i}(\cdot)$$ does not enter into this expression, bidder i's expected equilibrium payment given his signal is the same under all auction rules that satisfy (i) and (ii). Indeed, i's expected payment given $$s_{i}$$ is equal to:

E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1<si]=E[S2:nâˆ£S1:n=si]\mathbb{E}\left[S^{1: n-1} \mid S^{1: n-1}<s_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[S^{2: n} \mid S^{1: n}=s_{i}\right] E[S1:nâˆ’1âˆ£S1:nâˆ’1<siâ€‹]=E[S2:nâˆ£S1:n=siâ€‹]

So the seller's revenue is:

E[Â RevenueÂ ]=âˆ‘Esi[iÂ â€™sÂ expectedÂ paymentÂ âˆ£si]=E[S2:n]\mathbb{E}[\text { Revenue }]=\sum \mathbb{E}_{s_{i}}\left[i \text { 's expected payment } \mid s_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[S^{2: n}\right] E[Â RevenueÂ ]=âˆ‘Esiâ€‹â€‹[iÂ â€™sÂ expectedÂ paymentÂ âˆ£siâ€‹]=E[S2:n]

entry.title: åŒˆç‰™åˆ©ç®—æ³•
entry.content:
Hungarian Algorithm

The Hungarian matching algorithm , also called the Kuhn-Munkres algorithm, is a O(âˆ£Vâˆ£3)O\big(|V|^3\big)O(âˆ£Vâˆ£3)algorithm that can be used to find maximum-weight matchings in bipartite graphs , which is sometimes called the assignment problem . A bipartite graph can easily be represented by an adj matrix, where the weights of edges are the entries. Thinking about the graph in terms of an adjacency matrix is useful for the Hungarian algorithm.

The Hungarian Algorithm for Graphs

Given: the labeling lll, an equality graph Gl=(V,El)G_l=(V, E_l)Glâ€‹=(V,Elâ€‹), an initial matching MMM in GlG_lGlâ€‹, and an unmatched vertex uâˆˆVu \in VuâˆˆV and uâˆ‰Mu \notin Muâˆˆ/M

Augmenting the matching

  1. A path is augmenting for MMM in GlG_lGlâ€‹ if it alternates between edges in the matching and edges not in the matching, and the first and last vertices are free vertices, or unmatched, in MMM. We will keep track of a candidate augmenting path starting at the vertex uuu.

  2. If the algorithm finds an unmatched vertex vvv, add on to the existing augmenting path ppp by adding the uuu to vvv segment.

  3. Flip the matching by replacing the edges in MMM with the edges in the augmenting path that are not in MMM (in other words, the edges in Elâˆ’M)\left.E_l-M\right)Elâ€‹âˆ’M).

Improving the labeling

  1. SâŠ†XS \subseteq XSâŠ†X and TâŠ†YT \subseteq YTâŠ†Y, where SSS and TTT represent the candidate augmenting alternating path between the matching and the edges not in the matching.
  2. Let Nl(S)N_l(S)Nlâ€‹(S) be the neighbors to each node that is in SSS along edges in ElE_lElâ€‹ such that Nl(S)={vâˆ£âˆ€uâˆˆS:(u,v)âˆˆEl}N_l(S)=\{v \mid \forall u \in S:(u, v) \in E_l\}Nlâ€‹(S)={vâˆ£âˆ€uâˆˆS:(u,v)âˆˆElâ€‹}.
  3. If Nl(S)=TN_{l}(S)=TNlâ€‹(S)=T, then we cannot increase the size of the alternating path (and therefore can't further augment), so we need to improve the labeling.
  4. Let Î´l\delta_{l}Î´lâ€‹ be the minimum of l(u)+l(v)âˆ’w(u,v)l(u)+l(v)-w(u, v)l(u)+l(v)âˆ’w(u,v) over all of the uâˆˆSu \in SuâˆˆS and vâˆ‰Tv \notin Tvâˆˆ/T.
  5. Improve the labeling lll to lâ€²l^{\prime}lâ€² :

  • If râˆˆSr \in SrâˆˆS, then lâ€²(r)=l(r)âˆ’Î´ll^{\prime}(r)=l(r)-\delta_{l}lâ€²(r)=l(r)âˆ’Î´lâ€‹,

  • If râˆˆTr \in TrâˆˆT, then lâ€²(r)=l(r)+Î´ll^{\prime}(r)=l(r)+\delta_{l}lâ€²(r)=l(r)+Î´lâ€‹.

  • If râˆ‰Sr \notin Srâˆˆ/S and râˆ‰Tr \notin Trâˆˆ/T, then lâ€²(r)=l(r)l^{\prime}(r)=l(r)lâ€²(r)=l(r).

    lâ€²l^{\prime}lâ€² is a valid labeling and ElâŠ‚Elâ€²E_{l} \subset E_{l^{\prime}}Elâ€‹âŠ‚Elâ€²â€‹.

Putting it all together: The Hungarian Algorithm

  1. Start with some matching MMM, a valid labeling lll, where lll is defined as the labelling âˆ€xâˆˆX,yâˆˆYâˆ£l(y)=0,l(x)=maxâ¡yâˆˆY(w(x,y))\forall x \in X, y \in Y \mid l(y)=0, l(x)=\max _{y \in Y}(w(x, y))âˆ€xâˆˆX,yâˆˆYâˆ£l(y)=0,l(x)=maxyâˆˆYâ€‹(w(x,y)).
  2. Do these steps until a perfect matching is found (when MMM is perfect):
  • (a) Look for an augmenting path in MMM.
  • (b) If an augmenting path does not exist, improve the labeling and then go back to step (a).

entry.title: åº·ç±³ä¸»ä¹‰è’¸æ±½æœ‹å…‹è¯—
entry.content:
Reflections

RS Thomas

The furies are at home in the mirror;
it is their address.
Even the clearest water,
if deep enough can drown.

Never think to surprise them.
Your face approaching ever
so friendly is the white flag they ignore.
There is no truce with the furies. 

            A mirrorâ€™s temperature is always at zero. </br>
            It is ice in the veins. </br>
            Its camera is an X-ray. </br>

It is a chalice held out to you in silent communion,
where gaspingly you partake of a shifting
identity never your own.
